questions.prompt: This is a simple circuit that you've seen many times before. It consists of just two resistances in series, but instead of being driven by a battery, this circuit is connected to a device called a function generator. The function generator produces an alternating voltage at a frequency that you can adjust. Measure the voltages below (hint: remember to set the digital multimeter to AC voltage!) and click to import the multimeter reading to the answer box.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage across R1?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {question.answer = Math.round(10 * question.answer.reading)/10; sparks.vars.V = Math.round(10 * source.amplitude/Math.sqrt(2))/10; sparks.vars.V1 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r1.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; sparks.vars.V2 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r2.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V1 - question.answer) < .01){question.points_earned = 100; question.feedback = 'Excellent!'} else if(Math.abs(sparks.vars.V2 - question.answer) < .01) {question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R2.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V - question.answer) < .01){question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across both resistors.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(question.answer) < .0001){question.feedback = 'Make sure the DMM is set to measure AC voltage before you make the measurement.'; question.points_earned = 0}; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.V1 + ' volts'} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage across R2?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {question.answer = Math.round(10 * question.answer.reading)/10; sparks.vars.V = Math.round(10 * source.amplitude/Math.sqrt(2))/10; sparks.vars.V1 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r1.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; sparks.vars.V2 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r2.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V2 - question.answer) < .01){question.points_earned = 100; question.feedback = 'Excellent!'} else if(Math.abs(sparks.vars.V1 - question.answer) < .01) {question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R1.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V - question.answer) < .01){question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across both resistors.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(question.answer) < .0001){question.feedback = 'Make sure the DMM is set to measure AC voltage before you make the measurement.'; question.points_earned = 0}; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.V2 + ' volts'} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

subquestions.prompt: What is the total voltage across R1 and R2?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {question.answer = Math.round(10 * question.answer.reading)/10; sparks.vars.V = Math.round(10 * source.amplitude/Math.sqrt(2))/10; sparks.vars.V1 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r1.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; sparks.vars.V2 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r2.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V - question.answer) < .01){question.points_earned = 100; question.feedback = 'Excellent!'} else if(Math.abs(sparks.vars.V2 - question.answer) < .01) {question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R2.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V1 - question.answer) < .01){question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R1.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(question.answer) < .0001){question.feedback = 'Make sure the DMM is set to measure AC voltage before you make the measurement.'; question.points_earned = 0}; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.V + ' volts'} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

(Hint: click on the thumbnail of the function generator and move the slider to change the frequency.) Does changing the frequency affect the measurements you just made?
questions.shortPrompt: Effect of frequency on voltage drops

options.option: None of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Right! Changing the frequency has no effect on the voltage drop across a resistor.

options.option: Some of my measurements change when I change the frequency, but not all.
options.feedback: Actually, that is not so. Try again and see!

options.option: All of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Actually, that is not so. Try again and see!

questions.prompt: One last question: do the voltage drops across the two individual resistors always add up to the total voltage drop (across both resistors), regardless of the frequency?

options.feedback: That's right! Even though this is an alternating voltge source, the voltages across the two resistors always add up to the total voltage applied -- just as they did with the battery.

doc.title: Measuring an RC circuit with an oscilloscope

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   R1 = [r1.resistance] ohms
   C1 = [Math.round(10*c1.capacitance * 1000000)/10] microf
   R2 = [r2.resistance] ohms
   C2 = [Math.round(10*c2.capacitance * 1000000)/10] microf

questions.prompt:
Here are two RC circuits and an oscilloscope. The oscilloscope and the function generator share a common ground which is connected to the black lead of the function generator. Note that one of the oscilloscope probes (the yellow one) is permanently attached to ground so the oscilloscope measures all voltages with respect to ground.

The two circuits are subtly different. In the upper circuit the resistor is attached to the red lead of the function generator, in the lower circuit it is the capacitor that is attached to the red lead of the function generator.

This means that if you connect the probe to the junction between the resistor and the capacitor then in the upper circuit you are measuring the voltage across the resistor (which is proportional to the current through the circuit). But if you do the same measurement with the lower circuit you are measuring the voltage across the capacitor.

Set the frequency on the function generator and then make the measurements below.

subquestions.prompt: Measure the peak voltage across the resistor.
subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.R1 = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C1 = c1.capacitance; sparks.vars.f = question.meta.frequency; sparks.vars.V1 = source.amplitude; sparks.vars.Z1 = 1/(6.2832*sparks.vars.f*sparks.vars.C1); sparks.vars.Ztotal = Math.sqrt(Math.pow(sparks.vars.R1,2)+Math.pow(sparks.vars.Z1,2)); sparks.vars.Vr1 = Math.round(10*(sparks.vars.V1*sparks.vars.R1/sparks.vars.Ztotal))/10; sparks.vars.Vc1 = Math.round(10*(sparks.vars.V1*sparks.vars.Z1/sparks.vars.Ztotal))/10; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.Vr1 + ' volts'; var valueCorrect = false; var unitsCorrect = false; if(question.answer != '') {var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, sparks.vars.Vr1, 10); var unitsExist = !!parsedAnswer.units; if (unitsExist) {unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'}; question.points_earned = (valueCorrect ? 500 : 0) + (unitsCorrect ? 100 : 0); question.feedback = (valueCorrect ? 'You got the value correct' : 'You did not get the value correct') + (unitsCorrect ? ' and you got the units correct' : ' and you did not get the units correct')} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

subquestions.prompt: Without changing the frequency, measure the peak voltage across the capacitor
subquestions.scoring: question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.Vc1 + ' volts'; var valueCorrect = false; var unitsCorrect = false; if(question.answer != '') {var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, sparks.vars.Vc1, 10); var unitsExist = !!parsedAnswer.units; if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'}; question.points_earned = (valueCorrect ? 500 : 0) + (unitsCorrect ? 100 : 0); question.feedback = (valueCorrect ? 'You got the value correct' : 'You did not get the value correct') + (unitsCorrect ? ' and you got the units correct' : ' and you did not get the units correct')} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

questions.prompt: Now try changing the frequency and see if any of your measurements change. (Remember: to change the frequency, click on the thumbnail of the function generator and move the slider.) Set a different frequency and make the same measurements. Does changing the frequency affect the measurements you just made?
questions.shortPrompt: Measuring RC voltages at second frequency

subquestions.prompt: Measure the peak voltage across the resistor at this new frequency.
Without changing the frequency, measure the peak voltage across the capacitor

questions.prompt: Compare the new measurements to the old ones and answer the question below

options.option: None of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Wrong! Try again and be careful!

options.option: Some of my measurements change when I change the frequency, but not all.
options.feedback: That's right! The total voltage is still the same, but the voltage drops across the resistor and the capacitor change when you change the frequency.

options.option: All of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Actually, that is not so. Two of them change but the third measurement isn't affected by the frequency. Try again!

questions.prompt: Is the voltage across R and C equal to the voltage across R plus the voltage across C?

options.feedback: Wrong! The voltage drops across the components do not add up to the total applied voltage, the way they do with resistors.
Right! The voltage drops across the components do not add up to the total applied voltage, the way they do with resistors.

pages.notes: consent

questions.prompt:
Your school and your teacher/professor have adopted an exciting new project called SPARKS: Simulations for Performance Assessments that Report on Knowledge and Skills to be part of your electronics course. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation, helps students learn various topics in electronics by presenting realistic problems—similar to what they will see in the lab—simulated on a computer. Students receive instant feedback and detailed reporting as they work to develop their electronic lab skills in the SPARKS modules.

This project is being run by non-profit educational research companies: The Concord Consortium, located in Concord, Massachusetts, and CORD, located in Waco, Texas.

Although your professor and school have adopted this project, for us to gather data from you (your answers, computer logs), we require your signed consent. Your permission to participate in this project means that you may be 1) observed during your regular class time; 2) asked to answer some questions about the assessment process in the form of pencil and paper surveys, and 3) possibly interviewed (about your reaction to the programs).

Participation is not required and if you do not participate or decide to withdraw from the study, there will be no negative effect on your grade in the course. If you do participate, your data will be stripped of all identifying information and be simply assigned a unique identification number. A list of identification numbers and corresponding student names will be kept in a locked file cabinet.

If you have any questions, you may contact the project's Principal Investigator, Dr. Paul Horwitz, at 978-405-3223, or the Chair of the Human Subjects Institutional Review Board of the Concord Consortium, Dr. Andrew Zucker, at 978-405-3231.

Have you read the above and are you willing to participate in this study?

pages.notes: consent

This is a complicated circuit. The 12 resistors are connected along the edges of a cube -- each resistor is connected to exactly three others. The voltage is applied at two diagonal corners of the cube. To make it easier we've made all the resistors the same (100 ohms) and one of them, and only one, is shorted (not open). Your job is to figure out which one. (Note: R10, R11, and R12 are simply denoted as 10, 11, and 12, respectively, because there is no room on the resistor graphic for three-character labels.
Which resistor is shorted?

questions.prompt:

var natureOfFault; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r4.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r5.resistance} > 1e12)) {natureOfFault = 'Open'} else if ((${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r4.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r5.resistance} < 1e-5)) {natureOfFault = 'Shorted'}; if (question.answer === natureOfFault) {question.points_earned = 5} question.correct_answer = natureOfFault

When you hit submit, the frequency was  '+actualFrequency

subquestions.prompt: Now change the frequency again, record the value

doc.title: Measuring an RC circuit with an oscilloscope

pages.notes:
[source.amplitude = (Math.random()*40)+1; sparks.vars.Vs = source.amplitude; r1.resistance = (Math.random()*100) + 100; c1.capacitance = (5 * Math.random() + 1)*1.0e-6; console.log('At ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.initialFrequency + ' Hz') + ', VP = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.amplitude + ' volts') + ' Vrms = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.amplitude*0.707 + ' volts')); '']For this circuit:
   R1 = [Math.round(r1.resistance)] ohms
   C1 = [Math.round(10*c1.capacitance * 1000000)/10] microf
Click the oscilloscope or function generator to make adjustments.

questions.prompt: Here a function generator drives an RC circuit, measured with an oscilloscope. All voltages are measured with respect to ground, which is the black lead of the function generator. The yellow probe is connected to the red lead, so the yellow trace (channel A) measures the output voltage of the function generator. Click on the scope and adjust the settings to obtain a sine wave you can measure. Then answer the two questions below (be sure to include units).

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak voltage provided by the function generator?
subquestions.scoring: var R = r1.resistance; var C = c1.capacitance; var f = question.meta.frequency; var Vp = source.amplitude; var Vpp = 2 * Vp; var Zc = 1 / (6.2832 * f * C); var Zrc = Math.sqrt(R * R + Zc * Zc); var Vr = Vp * R / Zrc; var Vc = Vp * Zc / Zrc; var valueCorrect = false; var valueHalfCorrect = false; var unitsCorrect = false; var yellowProbePosition = question.meta.yellowProbe; var pinkProbePosition = question.meta.pinkProbe; var correctAnswer = Vp; question.correct_answer = Math.round(100 * correctAnswer) / 100 + ' volts'; if (question.answer !== '') { var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer, 10); var valueTwiceCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer * 2, 10); var valueVr = close(parsedAnswer.val, Vr, 10); var valueVpp = close(parsedAnswer.val, Vpp, 10); var unitsExist = !! parsedAnswer.units; if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'; } var quality = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality; var probesMeasuringVtotal = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L11' || yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL') || (pinkProbePosition == 'L11' || pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL')); var probesMeasuringVr = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L17' && (pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL' || pinkProbePosition == 'L23')) || (pinkProbePosition == 'L17' && (yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL' || yellowProbePosition == 'L23'))); question.points_earned = 0; if (unitsCorrect) { if (probesMeasuringVtotal) { if (valueCorrect) { question.feedback = 'You got the right answer (within 10%) with the right units! Well done!'; question.points_earned = 100; } else if (valueTwiceCorrect) { /*Reading peak-to-peak?*/ question.feedback = 'You may be reading the scale wrong. Remember, you're supposed to be measuring the peak voltage across the resistor, not the peak-to-peak voltage.'; } else if (valueVr && probesMeasuringVr) { /*Possible trace mixup*/ question.feedback = 'That looks like the voltage across the resistor, instead of the source.'; } else if (!valueCorrect) { question.feedback = 'Your measurement is incorrect. Remember, the display depends on the oscilloscope settings. Check to make sure you are interpreting the scale correctly.'; } } else if (probesMeasuringVtotal && (valueVp || valueVpp)) { question.feedback = 'Your measurement is incorrect. You may be measuring the voltage across the entire circuit by mistake.'; } else { question.feedback = 'You don't have the oscilloscope probes placed properly. Try again.'; } } else if (unitsExist) { question.feedback = 'You are not using voltage units.'; } else { question.feedback = 'You must supply a unit of measure with your value.'; } } else { question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'; }

subquestions.prompt: What source voltage would be measured by a digital multimeter?
subquestions.scoring: var R = r1.resistance; var C = c1.capacitance; var f = question.meta.frequency; var Vp = source.amplitude; var Vpp = 2 * Vp; var Zc = 1 / (6.2832 * f * C); var Zrc = Math.sqrt(R * R + Zc * Zc); var Vr = Vp * R / Zrc; var Vc = Vp * Zc / Zrc; var Vrms = Vp / Math.sqrt(2); var VRrms = Vr / Math.sqrt(2); var valueCorrect = false; var valueHalfCorrect = false; var unitsCorrect = false; var yellowProbePosition = question.meta.yellowProbe; var pinkProbePosition = question.meta.pinkProbe; var correctAnswer = Vrms; question.correct_answer = Math.round(100 * correctAnswer) / 100 + ' volts'; if (question.answer !== '') { var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer, 10); var valueTwiceCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer * 2, 10); var valueVp = close(parsedAnswer.val, Vp, 10); var valueVpp = close(parsedAnswer.val, Vpp, 10); var valueVr = close(parsedAnswer.val, Vr, 10); var value2Vr = close(parsedAnswer.val, 2 * Vr, 10); var valueVRrms = close(parsedAnswer.val, VRrms, 10); var value2VRrms = close(parsedAnswer.val, 2 * VRrms, 10); var unitsExist = !! parsedAnswer.units; var quality = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality; var probesMeasuringVtotal = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L11' || yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL') || (pinkProbePosition == 'L11' || pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL')); var probesMeasuringVr = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L17') || (pinkProbePosition == 'L17')); if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'; } question.points_earned = 0; if (unitsCorrect) { if (valueCorrect && probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'You got the right answer (within 10%) with the right units! Well done!'; question.points_earned = 100; } else if (valueTwiceCorrect && probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'Remember the DMM measures rms voltage. The rms voltage is the peak voltage multiplied by 0.7'; } else if (probesMeasuringVr && (valueVr || value2Vr || valueVRrms || value2VRrms)) { question.feedback = 'Your measurement is incorrect. You may be measuring the voltage across the resistor by mistake.'; } else if (!valueCorrect && probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'Your measurement is incorrect. Remember, the the DMM measures rms voltage. The rms voltage is the peak voltage multiplied by 0.7. Also, the display depends on the oscilloscope settings. Check to make sure you are interpreting the scale correctly.'; } else if (!probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'You don't have the oscilloscope probes placed properly. Try again.'; } } else if (unitsExist) { question.feedback = 'You are not using voltage units.'; } else { question.feedback = 'You must supply a unit of measure with your value.'; } if (quality < 0.2 && probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = question.feedback + 'The oscilloscope was not set up properly for you to make this measurement. For maximum accuracy you should see no more than one wavelength and it should fill the display from top to bottom. Check out tutorial #29, "Using an Oscilloscope."'; } } else { question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'; source.amplitude = (Math.random()*40)+1;  }

questions.prompt: Next, find the voltage drop across the capacitor. Since oscilloscopes measure voltages with respect to ground, you must measure the difference between the two leads of the capacitor using both probes and the A-minus-B function.

parsedAnswer.units; if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'; } var quality = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality; var probesMeasuringVtotal = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L11' || yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL') || (pinkProbePosition == 'L11' || pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL')); var probesMeasuringVr = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L17' && (pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL' || pinkProbePosition == 'L23')) || (pinkProbePosition == 'L17' && (yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL' || yellowProbePosition == 'L23'))); var probesMeasuringVc = ((yellowProbePosition == 'L17' && pinkProbePosition == 'L11') || (yellowProbePosition == 'L11' && pinkProbePosition == 'L17')); var probeNotConnected = (yellowProbePosition === null || pinkProbePosition === null); question.points_earned = 0; console.log('valueCorrect = ' + valueCorrect + ', unitsCorrect = ' + unitsCorrect + ', probesMeasuringVtotal = ' + probesMeasuringVtotal + ', probesMeasuringVr = ' + probesMeasuringVr + ', probesMeasuringVc = ' + probesMeasuringVc + ', probeNotConnected = ' + probeNotConnected); if (unitsCorrect) { if (probesMeasuringVc) { if (valueCorrect) { question.feedback = 'You got the right answer (within 10% ) and you used the right units! Half points for this one -- try again!'; question.points_earned = 50; } else if (valueTwiceCorrect) { question.feedback = 'You & #39;re supposed to be measuring the peak voltage, not the peak-to-peak voltage, across the capacitor.'; } else { question.feedback = 'The probes are set correctly but there's something wrong with your measurement. Remember to use the 'A - B' trace on the oscilloscope to measure the voltage across the capacitor.'; } } else if (probeNotConnected) { question.feedback = 'You need to use both probes to make this measurement.'; } else { question.feedback = 'You don't have the oscilloscope probes placed properly. doc.title: Measuring an RC circuit with an oscilloscope

pages.notes:
[source.amplitude = (Math.random()*40)+1; sparks.vars.Vs = source.amplitude; r1.resistance = (Math.random()*100) + 100; c1.capacitance = (5 * Math.random() + 1)*1.0e-6; console.log('At ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.initialFrequency + ' Hz') + ', VP = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.amplitude + ' volts') + ' Vrms = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.amplitude*0.707 + ' volts')); '']For this circuit:

   C1 = [Math.round(10*c1.capacitance * 1000000)/10] microf
Click the oscilloscope or function generator to make adjustments.

questions.prompt: Here a function generator drives an RC circuit. You can make measurements with an oscilloscope and a multimeter. The oscilloscope measures all voltages with respect to ground, which is the black lead of the function generator. The yellow probe is connected to the red lead, so the yellow trace (channel A) is measuring the output voltage of the function generator. Click on the scope and adjust the settings to obtain a sine wave you can measure.

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak voltage provided by the function generator as measured by the oscilloscope?
subquestions.scoring: /*Scoring for peak voltage oscope measurement*/ var R = r1.resistance; var C = c1.capacitance; var f = question.meta.frequency; var Vp = source.amplitude; var Vrms = Vp / Math.sqrt(2); var Zc = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * f * C); var Zrc = Math.sqrt(R * R + Zc * Zc); var Vr = Vp * R / Zrc; var Vc = Vp * Zc / Zrc; var yellowProbePosition = question.meta.yellowProbe; var pinkProbePosition = question.meta.pinkProbe; var qualityYellow = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[0]; var qualityPink = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[1]; var yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal = (yellowProbePosition == 'L11' || yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL'); var pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal = (pinkProbePosition == 'L11' || pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL'); var probesMeasuringVtotal = yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal || pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal; var yellowProbeMeasuringVr = (yellowProbePosition == 'L17'); var pinkProbeMeasuringVr = (pinkProbePosition == 'L17'); var probesMeasuringVr = yellowProbeMeasuringVr || pinkProbeMeasuringVr; var probesMeasuringVc = ((pinkProbePosition == 'L17') & (yellowProbePosition == 'L11') || (pinkProbePosition == 'L11') & (yellowProbePosition == 'L17')); var goodQuality = ((yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal & qualityYellow > 0.4) || (pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal & qualityPink > 0.4)); var unitsCorrect = false; console.log('qualityYellow = ' + qualityYellow + ', qualityPink = ' + qualityPink); var correctAnswer = Vp; question.correct_answer = Math.round(100 * correctAnswer) / 100 + ' volts'; question.points_earned = 0; sparks.vars.question1_answer = parse(question.answer).val; sparks.vars.question1_correct = false; if (question.answer !== '') { /*Question is not empty*/ var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var unitsExist = !! parsedAnswer.units; var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer, 10); var valueTwiceCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer * 2, 10); if (unitsExist) { /*Units exist*/ unitsCorrect = (parsedAnswer.units === 'V'); sparks.vars.question1_correct = valueCorrect & unitsCorrect; if (unitsCorrect) { if (valueCorrect & probesMeasuringVtotal & goodQuality) { question.feedback = 'You got within 10% of the right answer with the right units! Well done!'; question.points_earned = 100; } else if (valueCorrect & probesMeasuringVtotal & !goodQuality) { question.feedback = 'You got within 10% of the right answer with the right units. Congratulations!' + ' I noticed,though, that the oscilloscope settings were less than ideal for making the measurement. Were you guessing?'; question.points_earned = 90; } else if (valueTwiceCorrect & probesMeasuringVtotal) { /*Reading peak-to-peak?*/ question.feedback = 'Your answer is approximately twice the correct answer. Remember that the you were asked for the peak voltage, not the peak-to-peak voltage. Try again.'; question.points_earned = 10; } else if (!valueCorrect & probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'Wrong value for total voltage. Try again.'; } else if (!valueCorrect & !probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'You do not have the probes correctly placed to make this measurement.'; } } /*Units incorrect*/ else { question.feedback = 'You have the wrong units.'; } } else /*Units missing*/ { question.feedback = 'You must include units in your answer. A measurement is meaningless without units.'; } } else /*Question is empty*/ { question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'; }

subquestions.prompt: What voltage would a digital multimeter, set to AC voltage, measure? Make your prediction and enter the result below before actually making the measurement in the next step.
subquestions.scoring: /*Scoring for RMS voltage calculation*/ sparks.vars.question2_answer = parse(question.answer).val; console.log ('sparks.vars.question2_answer = ' + sparks.vars.question2_answer); var R = r1.resistance; var C = c1.capacitance; var f = question.meta.frequency; var Vp = source.amplitude; var Vpp = 2 * Vp; var Vrms = Vp / Math.sqrt(2); var Zc = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * f * C); var Zrc = Math.sqrt(R * R + Zc * Zc); var Vr = Vp * R / Zrc; var Vc = Vp * Zc / Zrc; var yellowProbePosition = question.meta.yellowProbe; var pinkProbePosition = question.meta.pinkProbe; var qualityYellow = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[0]; var qualityPink = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[1]; var yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal = (yellowProbePosition == 'L11' || yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL'); var pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal = (pinkProbePosition == 'L11' || pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL'); var probesMeasuringVtotal = yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal || pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal; var goodQuality = (yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal & (qualityYellow > 0.4)) || (pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal & (qualityPink > 0.4)); var unitsCorrect = false; var correctAnswer = Vrms; var answerFromQuestion1 = Math.round(100 * sparks.vars.question1_answer / Math.sqrt(2)) / 100; question.correct_answer = Math.round(100 * correctAnswer) / 100 + ' volts'; question.points_earned = 0; if (question.answer !== '') { /*Question is not empty*/ var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var unitsExist = !! parsedAnswer.units; var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer, 10); var valueCalculatedCorrectly = close(parsedAnswer.val, answerFromQuestion1, 10); if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = (parsedAnswer.units === 'V'); if (unitsCorrect) { if (valueCorrect) { question.feedback = 'You got within 10% of the right answer with the right units! Well done!'; question.points_earned = 100; } else if (valueCalculatedCorrectly) { /*Calculated correctly from incorrect measurement?*/ question.feedback = 'Your answer appears to be a correct calculation from the measurement you made' + ' but that measurement was wrong. Try again.'; question.points_earned = 20; } else { question.feedback = 'No, that is not what the DMM would measure.'; } } else { question.feedback = 'You have the wrong units.'; } } else { question.feedback = 'You must include units in your answer. A measurement is meaningless without units.'; } } else /*Question is empty*/ { question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'; }

subquestions.prompt: Now measure the voltage using the digital multimeter and enter the result below. Check to see whether the measurement matches your prediction.
subquestions.scoring: /*Scoring for DMM total voltage measurement*/ var R = r1.resistance; var C = c1.capacitance; var f = question.meta.frequency; var Vp = source.amplitude; var Vpp = 2 * Vp; var Vrms = Vp / Math.sqrt(2); var Zc = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * f * C); var Zrc = Math.sqrt(R * R + Zc * Zc); var Vr = Vp * R / Zrc; var Vc = Vp * Zc / Zrc; var yellowProbePosition = question.meta.yellowProbe; var pinkProbePosition = question.meta.pinkProbe; var qualityYellow = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[0]; var qualityPink = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[1]; var yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal = (yellowProbePosition == 'L11' || yellowProbePosition == 'powerPosL'); var pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal = (pinkProbePosition == 'L11' || pinkProbePosition == 'powerPosL'); var probesMeasuringVtotal = yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal || pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal; var goodQuality = (yellowProbeMeasuringVtotal & (qualityYellow > 0.4)) || (pinkProbeMeasuringVtotal & (qualityPink > 0.4)); var unitsCorrect = false; var correctAnswer = Vrms; question.correct_answer = Math.round(100 * correctAnswer) / 100 + ' volts'; console.log('Vrms = ' + Vrms + ', correctAnswer = ' + correctAnswer + ', question.correct_answer = ' + question.correct_answer); question.points_earned = 0; if (question.answer !== '') { /*Question is not empty*/ var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var unitsExist = !! parsedAnswer.units; var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer, 10); var valueSameAsCalculated = close(parsedAnswer.val, sparks.vars.question2_answer, 10); if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = (parsedAnswer.units === 'V'); if (unitsCorrect & valueCorrect & valueSameAsCalculated) { question.feedback = 'You got within 10% of the right answer with the right units! Well done!'; question.points_earned = 100; } else if (unitsCorrect & valueCorrect & !valueSameAsCalculated) { question.feedback = 'You got within 10% of the right value but your answer is not the same as the one you calculated.'; question.points_earned = 100; } else if (unitsCorrect & !valueCorrect) { question.feedback = 'That is the wrong value. Check to make sure the probes are in the right place and the multimeter is set to AC volts.'; question.points_earned = 0; } else if (!unitsCorrect) { question.feedback = 'You have the wrong units.'; } } else { question.feedback = 'You must include units in your answer. A measurement is meaningless without units.'; } } else /*Question is empty*/ { question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'; }

questions.prompt: Here a function generator drives an RC circuit. You can make measurements with an oscilloscope and a multimeter. The oscilloscope measures all voltages with respect to ground, which is the black lead of the function generator. The yellow probe is connected to the red lead, so the yellow trace (channel A) is measuring the output voltage of the function generator. Click on the scope and adjust the settings to obtain a sine wave you can measure.

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak voltage provided by the function generator as measured by the oscilloscope?

parsedAnswer.units; var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer, 10); var valueTwiceCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer * 2, 10); if (unitsExist) { /*Units exist*/ unitsCorrect = (parsedAnswer.units === 'V'); sparks.vars.question1_correct = valueCorrect & unitsCorrect; if (unitsCorrect) { if (valueCorrect & probesMeasuringVtotal & goodQuality) { question.feedback = 'You got within 10% of the right answer with the right units! Try again.'; question.points_earned = 10; } else if (!valueCorrect & probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'Wrong value for total voltage. Try again.'; } else if (!valueCorrect & !probesMeasuringVtotal) { question.feedback = 'You do not have the probes correctly placed to make this measurement.'; } } /*Units incorrect*/ else { question.feedback = 'You have the wrong units.'; } } else /*Units missing*/ { question.feedback = 'You must include units in your answer. [ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXC = function (c, f) { return (1/(2 * Math.PI * c * f)); }; sparks.vars.fXL = function (l, f) { return (2 * Math.PI * l * f); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XC = sparks.vars.fXC(sparks.vars.C, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XC); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VP, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VC = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VP, sparks.vars.XC, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log('- - - - - - -'); console.log('Recalc: At f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XC + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('VP = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VP + 'V') + ', VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT CAPACITANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function(x,unit) { if (Math.log10(x)<-6){ /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100*x*1e9)/100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHERS --- */ {return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit));} }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 5); /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VP = source.amplitude; sparks.vars.VPP = sparks.vars.VP * 2; sparks.vars.VRMS = sparks.vars.VP / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C = C1.getCapacitance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.R * sparks.vars.C); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.CLoc = C1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); console.log('Starting at: ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(source.initialFrequency + ' Hz') + ', VP = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VP + ' volts') + ' Vrms = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VP * 0.707 + ' volts')); questions.prompt: Here a function generator drives an RC circuit, measured with an oscilloscope. The yellow probe is initially connected to one of the function generator leads, measuring the voltage compared to ground. Click on the scope and adjust the settings to obtain a sine wave you can measure. Then answer the two questions below (be sure to include units).

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak voltage provided by the function generator?
subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- COMPARE MEAS WITH REASONABLE OSCOPE READING --- */ sparks.vars.checkCorrectV = function (measValue, actualValue) { var scaleArray = new Array(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2.5, 5, 10, 25, 50, 100); for (var i = scaleArray.length; i > 0; i--) { if (actualValue < scaleArray[i] * 4) { /* array here, since cannot be in Notes section */ maxDev = scaleArray[i] / 5 * 1.5; } } console.log('maxdev = ' + maxDev); if (Math.abs(actualValue - measValue) < maxDev) { return (1); /* 1 = less than 1.5 tics */ } else if (Math.abs(actualValue - measValue) < maxDev * 2) { return (0); /* 0 = less than 3 tics */ } else return (-1); /* -1 = more than 3 tics off */ }; /* --- CHECK meta.PROBE PLACED TO MEASURE target, TRUE or FALSE --- */ sparks.vars.probesMeasuring = function (meta, target) { var pinkProbe = meta.pinkProbe; var yellowProbe = meta.yellowProbe; var oscopeQuality = meta.oscopeScaleQuality; var status = -1; if (target === 'VP') { /* one probe on the power lead */ status = ((yellowProbe === 'powerPosL' || yellowProbe === 'L11') && oscopeQuality[0] > 0.2) || ((pinkProbe === 'powerPosL' || pinkProbe === 'L11') && oscopeQuality[1] > 0.2); } else if (target === 'VR') { /* one probe on the resistor lead */ status = (yellowProbe === 'L17' && oscopeQuality[0] > 0.2) || (pinkProbe === 'L17' && oscopeQuality[1] > 0.2); } else if (target === 'VC') { /* two probes across capacitor */ status = (yellowProbe === 'L17' && (pinkProbe === 'L11' || pinkProbe === 'powerPosL')) || (pinkProbe === 'L17' && (yellowProbe === 'L11' || yellowProbe === 'powerPosL')); } console.log('measuring '+ target + ' = ' + status + '  oscope quality = ' + oscopeQuality[0]); return status; };
subquestions.scoring: var f = question.meta.frequency; sparks.vars.Recalc(f); var correctAnswer = sparks.vars.VP; question.correct_answer = Math.round(100 * correctAnswer) / 100 + ' volts'; if (question.answer !== '') { var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var valueIsCorrect = sparks.vars.checkCorrectV(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer); var valueIsTwiceCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, correctAnswer * 2, 10); var valueIsVr = sparks.vars.checkCorrectV(parsedAnswer.val, sparks.vars.VR); var unitsExist = !! parsedAnswer.units; unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'; var quality = question.meta.oscopeScaleQuality[0]; question.points_earned = 0; console.log('valueIsCorrect=' + valueIsCorrect + ' valueIsVr=' + valueIsVr + ' unitsCorrect=' + unitsCorrect + ' quality=' + quality); if (unitsCorrect) { console.log('Units are correct.'); if (sparks.vars.probesMeasuring(question.meta, 'VP')) { if (valueIsCorrect === 1) { console.log('Value is correct.'); if (parsedAnswer.val === correctAnswer) { question.feedback = 'Good work measuring the signal voltage using the oscilloscope display (exactly right!) and with the right units, too! Well done!'; } else { question.feedback = 'Good work measuring the signal voltage using the oscilloscope display (close enough!) and with the right units, too! Well done!'; } question.points_earned = 100; } else { if (valueIsTwiceCorrect) { /* Reading peak-to-peak? */ question.feedback = 'Remember, you're supposed to be measuring the peak voltage across the resistor, not the peak-to-peak voltage.'; } else if (valueIsVr >= 0 && sparks.vars.probesMeasuring(question.meta, 'VR')) { /* measuring Vr */ question.feedback = 'This looks like your measurement across the resistor (not needed here), instead of the source. Try again.'; } else if (valueIsCorrect === 0) { /* slightly misreading oscope */ question.feedback = 'You are almost right. We 'll give you a few points. Try again, and see if you can you read the oscilloscope display a little more carefully for full points.'; question.points_earned = 20; } else question.feedback = 'Sorry, your value is incorrect. Either you misinterpreted the scale or your probes are improperly placed. Try again.'; } } else question.feedback = 'Did you use the oscilloscope and adjust the settings for a good display?'; } else if (unitsExist) { question.feedback = 'Your answer must include voltage units.'; } else { question.feedback = 'You must supply a unit of measure with your value.'; } } else { question.feedback = 'Please provide a measurement.'; }

questions.prompt: You've completed the first level, showing that you know how to measure the total voltage across the circuit, Vtot, as well as the voltage across the resistor, Vr, and the voltage across the capacitor, Vc. Now it's time to investigate how all these voltages vary with frequency. Click on the function generator to change the frequency up and down. Note how Vtot, Vr and Vc behave as you do this. (Hint: you can measure all three voltages without moving the oscilloscope probes!) Then answer the questions below.

questions.prompt: If you have gotten this far you've seen that the voltages across the resistor and the capacitor vary with the frequency, but the voltage across the whole circuit stays the same. This is because the impedance of the capacitor is a function of frequency. At some frequencies the capacitor acts like a short, at others it acts like an open. Play around with the circuit and then answer the questions below.

subquestions.prompt: Which of the following statements are true? (There may be more than one.)
subquestions.shortPrompt: Behavior of capacitor at different frequencies.
subquestions.correct_answer: Capacitors become more and more conductive as the frequency increases.

options.option: At high frequencies the capacitor acts like an open.
options.feedback: No, that's wrong. Remember the voltage across an open is high. Go back and check your measurements.

options.option: At high frequencies the capacitor acts like a short.
options.feedback: Yes that's right. The capacitor offers very little resistance at high frequencies.

options.option: At low frequencies the capacitor acts like an open.
options.feedback: Yes that's right. The capacitor let's very little current pass at low frequencies. It's almost like an open.

options.option: At low frequencies the capacitor acts like a short.
options.feedback: No, that's wrong. Remember the voltage across a short is very small. Go back and check your measurements.

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   R1 = [r1.nominalResistance] ohms
   R2 = [r2.nominalResistance] ohms
   R3 = [r3.nominalResistance] ohms
   E = 9.00 volts

doc.COMMENT: Bonus for time < 60 sec: 8 pts. Max score: 20 pts.

doc.title: Measuring Parallel Circuits

pages.notes:
The labeled values are:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R3 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r3.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   E = 9.00 volts

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: The resistors on the breadboard may have slightly different values than the labeled values. Use the DMM to measure the circuit.

doc.title: Troubleshooting Parallel Circuits

pages.notes:
Design values:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R3 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r3.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   E = 9.00 volts

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: The circuit above does not have a short, but one of the resistors is somehow defective. Which of the following describes the defective resistor? (Earn bonus points for fast work!)

options.option: R1 is open[if (r1.resistance<120) {r1.resistance=r1.resistance*10; r1.nominalResistance = r1.nominalResistance*10}; if (r2.resistance<120) {r2.resistance=r2.resistance*10; r2.nominalResistance = r2.nominalResistance*10}; if (r3.resistance<120) {r3.resistance=r3.resistance*10; r3.nominalResistance = r3.nominalResistance*10}; var upval = 13.146; var downval = 0.0735; var rand_case = Math.floor(Math.random()*9); switch (rand_case) { case 0: r1.resistance=1e20; r1.open=true; break; case 1: if (r1.resistance*downval>120){r1.resistance=r1.resistance*downval} else {r1.resistance=r1.resistance*upval}; break; case 2: r1.resistance=r1.resistance*upval; break; case 3: r2.resistance=1e20; r2.open=true; break; case 4: if (r2.resistance*downval>120){r2.resistance=r2.resistance*downval} else {r2.resistance=r2.resistance*upval}; break; case 5: r2.resistance=r2.resistance*upval; break; case 6: r3.resistance=1e20; r3.open=true; break; case 7: if (r3.resistance*downval>120){r3.resistance=r3.resistance*downval} else {r3.resistance=r3.resistance*upval}; break; case 8: r3.resistance=r3.resistance*upval; break; default: break; };  '']

questions.scoring: var badRName = 'Dunno'; var isOpen = ' is open'; var isBig = ' is far too large'; var isSmall = ' is far too small'; var ratioR1 = r1.resistance / r1.nominalResistance; var ratioR2 = r2.resistance / r2.nominalResistance; var ratioR3 = r3.resistance / r3.nominalResistance; var defect = ''; var numVMeasures = log.uniqueVMeasurements(); var numIMeasures = log.uniqueIMeasurements(); /* --- IDENTIFY BAD R --- */ if (r1.open || ratioR1 > 5 || ratioR1 < 0.2) { badRName = 'R1'; } else if (r2.open || ratioR2 > 5 || ratioR2 < 0.2) { badRName = 'R2'; } else if (r3.open || ratioR3 > 5 || ratioR3 < 0.2) { badRName = 'R3'; } if (r1.open || r2.open || r3.open) { defect = 'open'; } else { defect = 'far too '; if (Math.max(ratioR1, ratioR2, ratioR3) > 12) { defect = defect + 'large'; } else { defect = defect + 'small'; } } /* --- SCORE QUESTION --- */ question.correct_answer = badRName + ' is ' + defect; if (question.answer == question.correct_answer && (numVMeasures < 1) && (numIMeasures < 4) && (numIMeasures > 0)) { question.points_earned = 250; question.feedback = 'Bravo! ' + badRName + ' was indeed ' + defect + ' and you did it with amazingly few measurements to earn BONUS points!'; } else if (question.answer == question.correct_answer && (numVMeasures > 1)) { question.points_earned = 150; question.feedback = 'Yes!! ' + badRName + ' was indeed ' + defect + ', but did you learn anything by making all those voltage measurements? You should be able to solve this type problem with only current measurements.'; } else if (question.answer == question.correct_answer && (numIMeasures > 3)) { question.points_earned = 150; question.feedback = 'Yes! questions.scoring: var natureOfFault; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} > 1e12)) {natureOfFault = 'Open'} else if ((${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)) {natureOfFault = 'Shorted'}; if (question.answer === natureOfFault) {question.points_earned = 5} question.correct_answer = natureOfFault

questions.prompt: One of these resistors is bad. Which one is it?
questions.scoring: var badResistorName; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)) {badResistorName = 'R1'}  else if ((${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R2' } else if ((${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R3' } else if ((${r4.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r4.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R4' }; if (question.answer === badResistorName) {question.points_earned = 10} question.correct_answer = badResistorName

questions.prompt: Is it shorted or open?
questions.scoring: var natureOfFault; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r4.resistance} > 1e12)) {natureOfFault = 'Open'} else if ((${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r4.resistance} < 1e-5)) {natureOfFault = 'Shorted'}; if (question.answer === natureOfFault) {question.points_earned = 5} question.correct_answer = natureOfFault

doc.title: Understanding Series Resistances

questions.prompt: Consider the three breadboards above, using the same battery voltage and light bulbs. Which statement best explains the different bulb brightness?

options.option: More bulbs in series means less current, and so, less light output.
options.feedback: Bravo! The total resistance increases with additional bulbs. Ohm’s Law tells us that the battery will then deliver less current. And that means less power output by each bulb.

options.option: More bulbs in series means less voltage from the battery, and so, less light output.
options.feedback: No, the battery will always deliver about the same voltage. Try again.

options.option: More bulbs in series means less total resistance, and so, less light output.
options.feedback: No, actually resistors in   series will add their values. The total resistance when connected in series is greater. How will that make the circuit behave? Try again.

options.option: More bulbs in series quickly shorts out the battery, and so, soon the bulbs quit emitting light.
options.feedback: No, more resistors in series will reduce the current and so the battery will last longer.  Try again.

questions.prompt: If you were to lift one of the leads from the right-hand bulb in Case 2, what will happen?

options.option: The current will stop, and so all the bulbs would go out.
options.feedback:
That's right! The battery current must flow through all the parts of a series circuit, so breaking the circuit means zero current, and so no light.

You can advance to the next level.

options.option: All the voltage will be across the other bulb, so it will get brighter and the right-hand bulb will go out.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up. Try again.

options.option: All the voltage will be across the right-hand bulb, so it will get brighter and the left-hand bulb will go out.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up. Try again.

options.option: All the current will flow through the left-hand bulb, so it will get brighter.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up.

options.option: Since the total resistance is less, the bulbs will get brighter.
options.feedback: No, when one lead is lifted, the current stops, and so none of the bulbs will light up. The total resistance has nothing to do with this. Try again.

doc.title: Measuring Series Circuits

pages.notes:
The labeled values are:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R3 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r3.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: The resistors on the breadboard above are rated as shown in the Notes window, but probably have slightly different values. Use the DMM to measure the circuit above.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage drop across all the resistors?

options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r1.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R1. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r2.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R2. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r3.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R3. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Isn't this actually the current measurement? Use the DMM in voltage mode and measure across all three resistors.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R2+R1)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: This appears to be the voltage across two resistors. You need to measure across all three resistors.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R2+R3)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: This appears to be the voltage across two resistors. You need to measure across all three resistors.
Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across all three resistors. See the tutorial for more help.
Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across all three resistors. See the tutorial for more help.

subquestions.prompt: What is the current flowing through the whole circuit?

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Right! The same current passes through all the resistors in a series circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var ANS = 9*r1.resistance/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var ANS = 9*r2.resistance/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var ANS = 9*r3.resistance/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')*(1.03+0.03*Math.random()); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')*(0.97-0.03*Math.random()); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

subquestions.prompt: What is the actual total resistance value for this circuit?

options.feedback: Right! Using Ohm's Law with your measurements you found the actual total resistance of this circuit.

Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.
Did you make a calculation error? This is close to the correct resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.
Did you make a calculation error? This is close to the correct resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var RTOT=Math.toSigFigs(cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'),3); var nRTOT=Math.toSigFigs(cMath.rNominalSeries('r1','r2','r3'),3); var ANS = nRTOT; if (RTOT==nRTOT) {ANS=nRTOT*1.02;}; ANS] ohms
options.feedback: Did you just sum the labeled R values? You need to use the DMM to measure the circuit to determine the actual circuit resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.
Are you guessing? This is similar to the value for the current in the circuit. You need to calculate the resistance using the circuit voltage and the current. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R3 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r3.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]

doc.title: Measuring Series Circuits

pages.notes:
The labeled values are:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R3 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r3.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: The resistors on the breadboard above are rated as shown in the Notes window, but may have slightly different values. So, use the DMM to measure the circuit above and answer the questions below.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage drop across all the resistors?

options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r1.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R1. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r2.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V

options.feedback: Isn't this actually the current measurement? Use the DMM in voltage mode and measure across all three resistors.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R2+R1)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: This appears to be the voltage across two resistors. You need to measure across all three resistors.

options.feedback: Right! Using Ohm's Law with your measurements this is the actual total resistance of this circuit.

options.option: [var RTOT=Math.toSigFigs(cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'),3); var nRTOT=Math.toSigFigs(cMath.rNominalSeries('r1','r2','r3'),3); var ANS = nRTOT; if (RTOT==nRTOT) {ANS=nRTOT*1.02;}; ANS] ohms
options.feedback: Did you just sum the labeled R values? You need to use the DMM to measure the circuit to determine the actual circuit resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

doc.title: Measuring Series Circuits (advanced)

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: Use the DMM to measure the circuit above.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage drop across all the resistors?

options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

doc.title: Measuring Series Circuits (advanced)

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: Use the DMM to measure the circuit above.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage dropped across all the resistors?

options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

subquestions.prompt: What is the current flowing through the circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS =9/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Right! The same current passes through all the resistors in a series circuit.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

subquestions.prompt: What is the actual total resistance value for this circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = R1+R2+R3; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Right! Using Ohm's Law with your measurements you found the actual total resistance of this circuit.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var ANS = R1; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R2 = r2.resistance; var ANS = R2; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

options.feedback: Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R1+R2+R3)*Math.pow(10,3+Math.floor(Math.log10(R1+R2+R3))); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? This is similar to the value for the current in the circuit. You need to calculate the resistance using the circuit voltage and the current. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = (R1+R2+R3)*(1.03+0.03*Math.random()); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Did you make a calculation error? This is close to the correct resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = (R1+R2+R3)*(0.97-0.03*Math.random()); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms

options.option: [var R1=r1.resistance; var R2=r2.resistance; var R3=r3.resistance; var nR1=r1.nominalResistance; var nR2=r2.nominalResistance; var nR3=r3.nominalResistance; RTOT=Math.toSigFigs(R1+R2+R3,3); nRTOT=Math.toSigFigs(nR1+nR2+nR3,3); if (RTOT==nRTOT) {ANS=nRTOT*1.02;} else {ANS=nRTOT;}; ANS] ohms

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

doc.title: Measuring Series Circuits (advanced)

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: Use the DMM to measure the circuit above.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage drop across all the resistors?

options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

doc.title: Measuring to Find R in Series Circuits (advanced)

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

pages.notes: The resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current. But you can earn extra points for being efficient. If you can answer correctly while only making two measurements you'll get 100 bonus points. 50 more points if both of those are voltage measurements!

questions.prompt: One of the resistors is bad: either shorted or open.

subquestions.scoring: var numVMeasures = log.uniqueVMeasurements(); var numIMeasures = log.uniqueIMeasurements(); var numMeasures = numVMeasures + numIMeasures; var badResistorName = breadboard.getFault().label; question.points_earned = 0; question.correct_answer = badResistorName; if (question.answer == question.correct_answer && (numMeasures > 0)) {question.points_earned = 200; question.feedback = 'Yes! Resistor ' + question.answer + ' was bad.';} else if (question.answer == question.correct_answer) {question.feedback = 'Yes, resistor ' + question.answer + ' was bad, but you must measure to find that, not guess.';} else if (question.answer.length > 0 && (numMeasures > 0)) {question.feedback = 'No. ' + question.answer + ' was actually good!';} else if (question.answer.length > 0) {question.feedback = 'You must make a measurement to troubleshoot a circuit, not just guess.';} else if (numMeasures > 0) {question.feedback = 'You did not even try an educated guess!?';} else {question.feedback = 'You need to measure the circuit to find the faulty resistor.'}

You found the ' + natureOfFault + ' resistor, using amazing powers of deduction and only two voltage measurements. You earned 150 EXTRA bonus points!'; } else if (question.answer == question.correct_answer && (numMeasures == 2) && (numIMeasures > 0) && (question1points > 0)) { questions.points_earned = 100; question.feedback = 'You found the ' + natureOfFault + ' resistor using only two measurements but they weren't both voltage measurements. You earned 50 bonus points.'; } else if (question.answer == question.correct_answer && (numMeasures >= 3) && (question1points > 0)) { question.points_earned = 50; question.feedback = 'Right! Expected DMM values

   V2 = [Math.round(9*r2.resistance/(r1.resistance+r2.resistance+r3.resistance)/Math.pow(10,Math.floor(Math.log(9*r2.resistance/(r1.resistance+r2.resistance+r3.resistance))/Math.log(10))-2))*Math.pow(10,Math.floor(Math.log(9*r2.resistance/(r1.resistance+r2.resistance+r3.resistance))/Math.log(10))-2)] V
   V3 = [Math.round(9*r3.resistance/(r1.resistance+r2.resistance+r3.resistance)/Math.pow(10,Math.floor(Math.log(9*r3.resistance/(r1.resistance+r2.resistance+r3.resistance))/Math.log(10))-2))*Math.pow(10,Math.floor(Math.log(9*r3.resistance/(r1.resistance+r2.resistance+r3.resistance))/Math.log(10))-2)] V

doc.title: Calculating in Series-Parallel Circuits

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   R3 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r3.nominalResistance + 'Ω')]
   E = 9.00 volts

subquestions.prompt: Which resistor is the bad one?
subquestions.shortPrompt: Which resistor is the bad one?
subquestions.scoring: var badResistorName; var bonusAnswer = 'Hurray! You got the right answer in fewer than 5 measurements. You get 5 bonus points.'; var rightAnswer = 'You got the right answer but you made too many measurements so no bonus points for you!'; var wrongAnswer = 'No, that is not the bad resistor. Try again.';if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)) {badResistorName = 'R1'}  else if ((${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R2' } else if ((${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R3' } else if ((${r4.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r4.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R4' }; if ((question.answer === badResistorName) & (log.measurements() < 5)) {question.points_earned = 400; question.feedback = bonusAnswer} else if((question.answer === badResistorName) & (log.measurements() > 4)) {question.points_earned = 300; question.feedback = rightAnswer} else question.feedback = wrongAnswer; question.correct_answer = badResistorName;

var natureOfFault; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r4.resistance} > 1e12)) {natureOfFault = 'Open'} else if ((${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r4.resistance} < 1e-5)) {natureOfFault = 'Shorted'}; if (question.answer === natureOfFault) {question.points_earned = 50} question.correct_answer = natureOfFault

questions.prompt: One of the resistors above is defective.

subquestions.scoring: var badResistorName; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)) {badResistorName = 'R1'}  else if ((${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R2' } else if ((${r3.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)) { badResistorName = 'R3' }; if (question.answer === badResistorName) {question.points_earned = 300} question.correct_answer = badResistorName

var natureOfFault; if ((${r1.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r2.resistance} > 1e12)||(${r3.resistance} > 1e12)) {natureOfFault = 'Open'} else if ((${r1.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r2.resistance} < 1e-5)||(${r3.resistance} < 1e-5)) {natureOfFault = 'Shorted'}; if (question.answer === natureOfFault) {question.points_earned = 50} question.correct_answer = natureOfFault

questions.prompt: One, and only one, of these resistors is bad. Your job is to identify the faulted resistor and determine whether it is shorted or open. Extra bonus points for doing it without lifting a lead!

subquestions.scoring: var badResistorName = breadboard.getFault().label; var rightAnswer = 'You got it!'; var wrongAnswer = 'No, that is not the faulty resistor.'; var nullAnswer = 'You did not answer the question!'; question.correct_answer = badResistorName; if (question.answer == '') {question.feedback = nullAnswer} else if (question.answer === badResistorName) {question.points_earned = 100; question.feedback = rightAnswer} else {question.feedback = wrongAnswer}

var nullAnswer = 'You did not answer the question!'; var singleRightAnswer = 'Correct, but you did not identify the faulty resistor.'; var doubleRightNoBonus = 'Well done! You got them both right, but you did not get a bonus because you took more than five measurements and you lifted a lead.'; var measurementBonusAnswer = 'Excellent! You solved the problem in fewer than five measurements but you lifted a lead.  You get 200 bonus points but you could have gotten 400.'; var breaksBonusAnswer = 'Excellent!  You solved the problem without lifting a lead but you used more than four measurements. You get 200 bonus points but you could have gotten 400.'; var doubleBonusAnswer = 'Excellent! You solved the problem in fewer than five measurements and without lifting a lead. You get 400 bonus points!'; var wrongAnswerShorted = 'No the resistor was open, not shorted.'; var wrongAnswerOpen = 'No the resistor was shorted, not open.'; var wrongResistor = 'You got the fault right, but on the wrong resistor! That could have been a lucky guess. Try again.'; if (breadboard.getFault().open) { natureOfFault = 'Open' } else if (breadboard.getFault().shorted) { natureOfFault = 'Shorted' }; question.correct_answer = natureOfFault; if (question.answer == '') { question.feedback = nullAnswer } else if (question.answer === natureOfFault) { if (sparks.sparksSectionController.currentPage.questions[0].points_earned > 99) { if (log.measurements() < 5) { if (log.connectionBreaks() == 0) { question.points_earned = 500; question.feedback = doubleBonusAnswer; } else if (log.connectionBreaks > 0) { question.points_earned = 250; question.feedback = measurementBonusAnswer; } } else if (log.measurements() > 4) { if (log.connectionBreaks() == 0) { question.points_earned = 250; question.feedback = breaksBonusAnswer; } else if (log.connectionBreaks > 0) { question.points_earned = 150; question.feedback = doubleRightNoBonus; } } } else { question.points_earned = 150; question.feedback = wrongResistor; } } else if (natureOfFault === 'Open') { question.points_earned = 0; question.feedback = wrongAnswerOpen } else if (natureOfFault === 'Shorted') { question.points_earned = 0; question.feedback = wrongAnswerShorted } console.log('Number of measurements = ' + log.measurements()); console.log('correct answer = ' + sparks.sparksSectionController.currentPage.questions[0].correct_answer + ' ' + question.correct_answer); var leadLifts = log.connectionBreaks(); console.log('Number of lead lifts = ' + leadLifts)

questions.prompt: Examine the unit conversions to the right.

This time there are only two resistors, but believe it or not the problem is actually harder than when there were three! That's because it is hard to tell the difference between one resistor being shorted and the other being open. Hint: you'll have to make a current measurement.
