doc.title: How to use an oscilloscope to measure voltages
Measuring Series Circuits

pages.notes:
The resistor values are:
   R1 = from [${r1.minimumResistance}] to [${r1.maximumResistance}] ohms
   R2 = [${r2.nominalResistance}] ohms
   R3 = from [${r3.minimumResistance}] to [${r3.maximumResistance}] ohms

Actually, the resistance function on this meter works! So, go ahead and measure the resistance!

questions.prompt: Can you adjust the values of R1 and R3 in the circuit above to get a voltrage drop of 3.5 V across one of the resistors?

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage drop across all the resistors?

options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r1.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R1. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r2.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R2. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = ${r3.resistance}*9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! This is the voltage measured across just one resistor, R3. You need to measure across all three resistors to find the voltage supplied to the circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Isn't this actually the current measurement? Use the DMM in voltage mode and measure across all three resistors.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R2+R1)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: This appears to be the voltage across two resistors. You need to measure across all three resistors.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R2+R3)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: This appears to be the voltage across two resistors. You need to measure across all three resistors.
Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across all three resistors. See the tutorial for more help.
Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across all three resistors. See the tutorial for more help.

subquestions.prompt: What is the current flowing through the whole circuit?

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Right! The same current passes through all the resistors in a series circuit.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r2','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r3'); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var ANS = 9*r2.resistance/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var ANS = 9/cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3')*(0.97-0.03*Math.random()); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

subquestions.prompt: What is the actual total resistance value for this circuit?

options.feedback: Right! Using Ohm's Law with your measurements you found the actual total resistance of this circuit.

Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

Did you make a calculation error? This is close to the correct resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var RTOT=Math.toSigFigs(cMath.rSeries('r1','r2','r3'),3); var nRTOT=Math.toSigFigs(cMath.rNominalSeries('r1','r2','r3'),3); var ANS = nRTOT; if (RTOT==nRTOT) {ANS=nRTOT*1.02;}; ANS] ohms
options.feedback: Did you just sum the labeled R values? You need to use the DMM to measure the circuit to determine the actual circuit resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.
Are you guessing? This is similar to the value for the current in the circuit. You need to calculate the resistance using the circuit voltage and the current. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

pages.notes:
The labeled resistor values are:
   R1 = [${r1.nominalResistance}] ohms
   R2 = [${r2.nominalResistance}] ohms
   R3 = [${r3.nominalResistance}] ohms
Note that the actual resistances may differ from the labeled values.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: For the resistors in the breadboard circuit above, use the DMM to measure the voltages across each and the current through each.

doc.title: Dividing variable voltage with series circuits

pages.notes:
[ /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); sparks.vars.V = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.V1 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r1.resistance / (r1.resistance + r2.resistance)) / 10; sparks.vars.V2 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r2.resistance / (r1.resistance + r2.resistance)) / 10; sparks.vars.VS = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V) / 10; sparks.vars.R1Loc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.R2Loc = r2.getNodes(); sparks.vars.Score = 0; '']For this circuit:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.resistance + 'ohms')]
   R2 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r2.resistance + 'ohms')]

questions.prompt: The function generator here serves as an AC power supply for this resistor circuit. You can change the AC frequency. Use the DMM to measure the voltages in this circuit to answer the questions below. The Read Multimeter buttons will copy your DMM readings.

subquestions.prompt:
At a low frequency (< 1 kHz), use the DMM to measure:
Supply voltage VPS
subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { nodes = component.getNodes(); return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe + ' dmmDial: ' + meta.dmmDial); if (meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') {allow = 3;} else {allow = 7;} if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1) || close(meta.val, sparks.vars.V1, allow)) { console.log('Measured R1 where R = ' + sparks.vars.R1 + ' ohms'); return ('R1'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r2) || close(meta.val, sparks.vars.V2, allow)) { console.log('Measured R2 where R = ' + sparks.vars.R2 + ' ohms'); return ('R2'); } else if (close(sparks.vars.VS, meta.val, allow)) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R1 or R2 or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK MEASURE OF x STORED IN q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== Checking measurements for this question:'); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; q.tutorial = 'tutorial-27'; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { q.meta.val = ''; /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ { q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.'; } } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { q.meta.val = ''; /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM, set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.correct_answer = q.answer; q.points_earned = q.points; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but need to use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement !== -1) /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ { if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, although the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ if ((probePlacement == 'R1' && x == 'R2') || (probePlacement == 'R2' && x == 'R1') || target == sparks.vars.V - q.answer) { q.feedback = 'Did you get the measures from the two resistors reversed? Try again.'; } else { q.feedback = 'Please measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V')); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');
sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.V1, 'R1');
sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.V2, 'R2');

questions.prompt:
Click the function generator and increase to a high AC frequency: over 5 kHz. Measure the voltage drops again and compare to your previous readings.
What effect does the higher frequency have on measures of VR across these series resistors?
questions.shortPrompt: Effect of frequency on voltage drops

options.option: No effect. The voltage drops stayed the same.
At the higher frequency the smaller resistor had a smaller voltage drop; the larger resistor had a larger drop.
At the higher frequency the larger resistor had a smaller voltage drop; the smaller resistor had a larger drop.
At the higher frequency both the voltage drops were larger.
At the higher frequency both the voltage drops were smaller.

questions.scoring: question.correct_answer = 'No effect in resistive circuits.'; if (question.answer !== null) { myAns = 'No effect'; if (question.answer.indexOf(myAns) > -1) { /* --- CORRECT RESPONSE CHOSEN --- */ if (log.measurements() != sparks.vars.Measures) { /* --- MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ if (sparks.vars.Score >2) { /* --- BRAVO! --- */ question.points_earned = 40; question.feedback = 'Right! Frequency has no effect on voltages in a purely resistive circuit.'; } else { /* --- ANSWER WITHOUT GOOD MEASURES --- */ question.points_earned = 5; question.feedback = 'That is right, but can you verify this with correct measurements?'; } } else { question.points_earned = 10; question.feedback = 'That is correct, but can you change the frequency and verify this with measurements?'; } } else { question.feedback = 'No, that is not the case. Try again and see!'; } } else { question.feedback = 'Measure your circuit and find out!'; question.points_earned = 0; }

questions.prompt: Consider the voltage drops you measured above. How do the drops by each resistor compare with the voltage supplied by the function generator?

options.option: In AC, the sum of voltages across the resistors always equals the voltage supplied by the function generator.
In AC, the sum of voltages across the resistors is always less than the voltage supplied.
In AC, the sum of the voltages across the resistors is always more than the voltage supplied.
In AC, the sum of the voltages across the resistors is greater when the frequency is increased.
In AC, the sum of the voltages across the resistors is less when the frequency is decreased.

questions.scoring: question.correct_answer = 'In resistive circuits, sum of voltage drops equals voltage supplied.'; question.feedback = 'Look at your measures to answer this question.'; question.points_earned = 0; if (question.answer !== null) { myAns = 'always equals'; if (question.answer.indexOf(myAns) > -1) { question.points_earned = 30; question.feedback = 'Right! The AC voltage drops across resistors always add up to the supplied voltage—same as with DC sources.'; } else { question.feedback = 'Really? Did your voltages change at all at different frequencies? Try measuring again and confirm this.'; } }

circuit.comment: at this freq, L = X, in milliHenrys

pages.notes:
[ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXL = function (L, f) { return (2 * Math.PI * L * f); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XL = sparks.vars.fXL(sparks.vars.L, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XL); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VL = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XL, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log(''); console.log('Recalc: f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XL + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Predicted VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT INDUCTANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function(x,unit) { if (Math.log10(x)<-6){ /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100*x*1e9)/100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHER --- */ {return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit));} }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.L = L1.getInductance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = sparks.vars.R / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.L); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.LLoc = L1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); '']For this circuit:
   R1 = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.resistance + ' ohms')]
   L1 = [sparks.vars.convertNano(L1.getInductance(),'H')]

questions.prompt: Here is a resistor R and inductor L in series, powered by the function generator: an AC power supply (PS). Since the inductor responds to different frequencies, use the slider on the function generator to explore the AC voltages in this circuit.

subquestions.prompt:
At a low frequency (< 1 kHz), use the DMM to measure:
Supply voltage VPS
subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fChange = function (f) { /* --- HOW MANY FREQ CHANGES? --- */ z = 0; y = f.sort(); len = y.length; for (var i = 1; i < len; i++) { if (y[i] != y[i - 1]) { z++; } } return (z); }; /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { nodes = component.getNodes(); return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe); if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { console.log('Measured R1 where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R1'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, L1)) { console.log('Measured L1 where L = ' + sparks.vars.L + ' H'); return ('L1'); } else if (close(sparks.vars.VS, meta.val, 0.5)) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R1 or L1 or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK MEASURE OF x STORED IN q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== Checking measurements for this question:'); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ {q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.';} } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement !== -1) /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ { if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VS SCORING AT FREQ F1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');

questions.prompt:
As you can see, the voltage drops across the two components do not add up to the supply voltage as they did with a pair of resistors. And they behave differently at different frequencies, too!
When the frequency increases, how would you summarize the voltage changes in the series-RL circuit?

options.option: The voltage across the resistor decreases, and across the inductor increases.
The voltage across the resistor increases, and across the inductor decreases.
The voltage across both the resistor and inductor increase.
The voltage across both the resistor and inductor decrease.
No change. The voltage across the resistor and inductor remain the same.

questions.scoring: if (question.answer.indexOf('resistor decreases')>0) { question.correct_answer = 'VR decreases, VL increases'; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { question.feedback = 'Correct! The inductor impedes more at high frequencies, reducing ' + 'the circuit current, and hence the voltage across R.'; question.points_earned = 50; } else { question.feedback = 'Yes, the inductor impedes more at high frequencies, ' + 'but you did not record any voltages with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 10; } } else { question.correct_answer = 'VR and VL are affected!'; question.feedback = 'No, try again and look closely at your measurements with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 0; }

[ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXL = function (L, f) { return (2 * Math.PI * L * f); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XL = sparks.vars.fXL(sparks.vars.L, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XL); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VL = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XL, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log(''); console.log('Recalc: f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XL + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Predicted VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT INDUCTANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function(x,unit) { if (Math.log10(x)<-6){ /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100*x*1e9)/100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHERS --- */ {return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit));} }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ /* --- CONSTANT FOR TEST source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); --- */ /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.L = L.getInductance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = sparks.vars.R / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.L); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.LLoc = L.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); '']For this circuit:
   R = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.resistance + ' ohms')]
   L = [sparks.vars.convertNano(L.getInductance(),'H')]

questions.prompt: Here a resistor R and inductor L in series are connected to an AC power supply (PS). Since the inductor responds to different frequencies, use the slider on the power supply to explore how the AC voltage varies in this circuit with different frequencies. (Hint: Measure with the DMM and click Read Multimeter.)

subquestions.prompt:
At a low frequency (< 1 kHz), use the DMM to measure:
Voltage VPS (across circuit)
subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fChange = function (f) { /* --- HOW MANY FREQ CHANGES? --- */ z = 0; y = f.sort(); len = y.length; for (var i = 1; i < len; i++) { if (y[i] > y[i - 1]) { z++; } } return (z); }; /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { nodes = component.getNodes(); return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); };/* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { if(component == 'PS') {nodes = 'gnd,powerPosL';} else nodes = component.getNodes(); /* --- allow for probes on power rails --- */ if (nodes.indexOf('L9') >-1) {nodes+= ',powerPosL';} else if (nodes.indexOf('powerPosL') >-1) {nodes+= ',L9';} if (nodes.indexOf('L21') >-1) {nodes+= ', gnd';} else if (nodes.indexOf('gnd') >-1) {nodes+= ',L21';} if(component == 'PS') {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure PS via ' + nodes + ' ?');} else {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure ' + component.UID + ' via ' + nodes + ' ?');} return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); /* --- RETURNS BOOLEAN RESULT --- */ }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe); if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { console.log('Measured R where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, L)) { console.log('Measured L where L = ' + sparks.vars.L + ' H'); return ('L'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, 'PS')) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R or L or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK MEASURE OF x STORED IN q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== Checking measurements of ' + x + ' for this question:'); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ {q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.';} } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement) /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ { if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VS SCORING AT FREQ F1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');

questions.prompt:
As you can see, the voltage drops VR and VL across the two components do not add up to the supply voltage VPS, as they did with a pair of resistors. And they vary with different frequencies, too!
When the frequency increases, which of these statements best summarizes the voltages in the series-RL circuit?

options.option: The voltage across the resistor decreases, and across the inductor increases.
The voltage across the resistor increases, and across the inductor decreases.
The voltage across both the resistor and inductor increase.
The voltage across both the resistor and inductor decrease.
No change. The voltage across the resistor and inductor remain the same.

questions.scoring: if (question.answer.indexOf('resistor decreases') > 0) { question.correct_answer = 'VR decreases, VL increases'; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- right answer and frequencies were changed --- */ points = sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[3].points_earned + sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[4].points_earned; if(points) { /* --- and got here by answering previous questions OK --- */ question.feedback = 'Correct! As you saw, the inductor impedes more at high frequencies, reducing ' + 'the circuit current, and hence the voltage across R. Feel free to experiment more, or repeat with another circuit.'; question.points_earned = 50; } else { /* --- or unable to answer the previous questions correctly --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the inductor impedes more at high frequencies, but were you able to measure and verify that? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with another circuit and earn more points.' ; question.points_earned = 10; } } else { /* --- right answer, but frequencies not explored --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the inductor impedes more at high frequencies, but did you actually measure any voltages at different frequencies? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with another circuit and earn more points.'; question.points_earned = 10; } } else { /* --- incorrect answer --- */ question.correct_answer = 'VR and VL are affected!'; question.feedback = 'No, try again and look closely at your measurements with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 0; }

/* --- RETURNS BOOLEAN RESULT --- */ }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe); if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { console.log('Measured R where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, L)) { console.log('Measured L where L = ' + sparks.vars.L + ' H'); return ('L'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, 'PS')) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R or L or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK MEASURE OF x STORED IN q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== Checking measurements for this question:'); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ { q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.'; } } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement) /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ { if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VS SCORING AT FREQ F1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');

subquestions.prompt: If VPS were all applied to the resistor R, so that VR equals VPS, we could obtain maximum power from the circuit. But because of the inductance from L in this AC circuit, as the frequency increases, VR decreases, and the power available to R also decreases. At what voltage value VR will it's power be reduced to half the maximum value?

options.option: [ /* --- FIRST OPPORTUNITY TO DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXL = function (L, f) { return (2 * Math.PI * L * f); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XL = sparks.vars.fXL(sparks.vars.L, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XL); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VL = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XL, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log(''); console.log('Recalc: f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XL + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Predicted VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT INDUCTANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function (x, unit) { if (Math.log10(x) < -6) { /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100 * x * 1e9) / 100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHER --- */ { return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit)); } }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 300 + 160) / 10; /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.L = L.getInductance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = sparks.vars.R / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.L); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.LLoc = L.getNodes(); sparks.vars.mySqrt2 = '√2 '; sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); /* --- USE INITIAL FREQUENCY FOR DISTRACTERS --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); /* --- create distracters here and use them in scoring --- */ sparks.vars.a0 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS / Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk0 = 'Good! The circuit will have half the maximum power at VPS times 0.707, or VPS divided by ' + sparks.vars.mySqrt2 + '. '; sparks.vars.pts0 = 50; sparks.vars.a1 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS / 2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk1 = 'No, this is just half the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts1 = 0; sparks.vars.a2 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk2 = 'No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts2 = 0; sparks.vars.a3 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS * 2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk3 = 'No, that is twice the supply voltage, VPS. The inductor will cause VR to be less than the supply voltage. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts3 = 0; sparks.vars.a4 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk4 = 'No, you chose the full supply voltage value, VPS. Reduced power will occur with reduced voltage across R. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts4 = 0; sparks.vars.a5 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS * Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk5 = 'No, that is even more than the supply voltage, VPS. The inductor will cause VR to be less than the supply voltage. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts5 = 0; sparks.vars.a6 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL * Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk6 = 'No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts6 = 0; sparks.vars.a7 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR * Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk7 = 'No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts7 = 0; sparks.vars.a0;]

subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.a0; question.points = sparks.vars.pts0; question.points_earned = 0; if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a0) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk0; question.points_earned = sparks.vars.pts0; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a1) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk1; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a2) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk2; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a3) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk3; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a4) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk4; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a5) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk5; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a6) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk6; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a7) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk7; }

questions.prompt:
What is the cutoff frequency for this circuit?
(pick the closest value)
questions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); /* --- update values since frequency may have changed --- */ question.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Cutoff + 'Hz'); question.points = 50; if (question.answer == question.correct_answer) { /* --- chosen answer is correct --- */ if (sparks.vars.dbugProbes(question.meta) == 'R' && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- probes placed right and frequency changes detected --- */ question.feedback = 'Right on! Near this frequency, the inductor "impedes" half the maximum circuit power. This is called the cutoff frequency.'; question.points_earned = 50; } else { /* --- appears to be lucky guess --- */ question.feedback = 'Wow, did you guess at that answer? You need to measure VR while changing the frequency and watching for the voltage that reduces the power by half. Check out the tutorial.'; question.points_earned = 0; } } else { /* --- chosen answer is incorrect --- */ if (sparks.vars.dbugProbes(question.meta) == 'R') { /* --- measurements were made --- */ do_measure = ''; } else { do_measure = 'measure VR and '; } question.feedback = 'No. You need to ' + do_measure + 'find the frequency that drops the voltage to reduce the power to half of the maximum possible value. Check out the tutorial.'; question.points_earned = 0; }

doc.title: AC Circuit with Series Resistor and Capacitor

pages.notes:
[/* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXC = function (c, f) { return (1/(2 * Math.PI * c * f)); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XC = sparks.vars.fXC(sparks.vars.C, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XC); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VC = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XC, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log(''); console.log('Recalc: f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XC + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Predicted VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT CAPACITANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function(x,unit) { if (Math.log10(x)<-6){ /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100*x*1e9)/100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHER --- */ {return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit));} }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C = C1.getCapacitance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.R * sparks.vars.C); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.CLoc = C1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); '']For this circuit:

if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. questions.prompt:
As you can see, the voltage drops across the two components do not add up to the supply voltage as they do with a pair of resistors. And they behave differently at different frequencies, too!
When the frequency increases, how would you summarize the voltage changes in the series-RC circuit?

options.option: The voltage across the resistor increases, and across the capacitor decreases.
The voltage across the resistor decreases, and across the capacitor increases.
The voltage across both the resistor and capacitor increase.
The voltage across both the resistor and capacitor decrease.
No change. The voltage across the resistor and capacitor remain the same.

questions.scoring: if (question.answer.indexOf('resistor increases')>0) { question.correct_answer = 'VR increases, VC decreases'; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { question.feedback = 'Correct! The capacitor impedes less at high frequencies, permitting ' + 'more circuit current, and hence also more voltage across R.'; question.points_earned = 50; } else { question.feedback = 'Yes, the capacitor impedes less at high frequencies, ' + 'but you did not record any voltages with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 10; } } else { question.correct_answer = 'VR and VC are affected!'; question.feedback = 'No, try again and look closely at your measurements with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 0; }

No, that is the full supply voltage. Reduced power will occur with reduced voltage across R. Check the tutorial for more help.
No, that is more than the supply voltage. Reduced power will occur with reduced voltage across R. Check the tutorial for more help.
No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage. Check the tutorial for more help.
No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage. Check the tutorial for more help.

pages.notes:
[ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXC = function (C, f) { return (1/(2 * Math.PI * C * f)); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XC = sparks.vars.fXC(sparks.vars.C, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XC); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VC = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XC, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log(''); console.log('Recalc: f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XC + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Predicted VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT CAPACITANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function (x, unit) { if (Math.log10(x) < -6) { /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100 * x * 1e9) / 100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHERS --- */ { return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit)); } }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C = C.getCapacitance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.R * sparks.vars.C); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.CLoc = C.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); '']For this circuit:
   R = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.resistance + ' ohms')]
   C = [sparks.vars.convertNano(C.getCapacitance(),'f')]

questions.prompt: Here a resistor R and capacitor C in series are connected to an AC power supply (PS). Since the capacitor responds to different frequencies, use the slider on the power supply to explore how the AC voltage varies in this circuit with different frequencies. (Hint: Measure with the DMM and click Read Multimeter.)

subquestions.prompt:
At a low frequency (< 1 kHz), use the DMM to measure:
Voltage VPS (across circuit)
subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fChange = function (f) { /* --- HOW MANY FREQ CHANGES? --- */ z = 0; y = f.sort(); len = y.length; for (var i = 1; i < len; i++) { if (y[i] > y[i - 1]) { z++; } } return (z); }; /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { if(component == 'PS') {nodes = 'gnd,powerPosL';} else nodes = component.getNodes(); /* --- allow for probes on power rails --- */ if (nodes.indexOf('L9') >-1) {nodes+= ',powerPosL';} else if (nodes.indexOf('powerPosL') >-1) {nodes+= ',L9';} if (nodes.indexOf('L21') >-1) {nodes+= ', gnd';} else if (nodes.indexOf('gnd') >-1) {nodes+= ',L21';} if(component == 'PS') {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure PS via ' + nodes + ' ?');} else {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure ' + component.UID + ' via ' + nodes + ' ?');} return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); /* --- RETURNS BOOLEAN RESULT --- */ }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe); if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { console.log('Measured R where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, C)) { console.log('Measured C where C = ' + sparks.vars.C + ' H'); return ('C'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, 'PS')) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R or C or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK MEASURE OF x STORED IN q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== Checking measurements for this question:'); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ { q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.'; } } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement !== -1) { /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VS SCORING AT FREQ F1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');

subquestions.shortPrompt: Voltage across R at low f
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VR SCORING AT FREQ1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VR, 'R');

subquestions.shortPrompt: Voltage across C at low f
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VL SCORING AT FREQ F1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VC, 'C');

subquestions.scoring: /* --- VL SCORING AT FREQ F2 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VC, 'C');

questions.prompt:
As you can see, the voltage drops VR and VC across the two components do not add up to the supply voltage VPS, as they did with a pair of resistors. And they vary with different frequencies, too!
When the frequency increases, which of these statements best summarizes the voltages in the series-RC circuit?

options.option: The voltage across the resistor decreases, and across the capacitor increases.
The voltage across the resistor increases, and across the capacitor decreases.
The voltage across both the resistor and capacitor increase.
The voltage across both the resistor and capacitor decrease.
No change. The voltage across the resistor and capacitor remain the same.

questions.scoring: if (question.answer.indexOf('resistor increases') > 0) { question.correct_answer = 'VR increases, VC decreases'; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- right answer and frequencies were changed --- */ points = sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[3].points_earned + sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[4].points_earned; if(points) { /* --- and got here by answering previous questions OK --- */ question.feedback = 'Correct! As you saw, the capacitor impedes less at high frequencies, allowing greater current, and hence greater voltage across R. Feel free to experiment more, or repeat with another circuit.'; question.points_earned = 50; } else { /* --- or unable to answer the previous questions correctly --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the capacitor impedes less at high frequencies, but were you able to measure and verify that? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with another circuit and earn more points.' ; question.points_earned = 10; } } else { /* --- right answer, but frequencies not explored --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the capacitor impedes less at high frequencies, but did you actually measure any voltages at different frequencies? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with another circuit and earn more points.'; question.points_earned = 10; } } else { /* --- incorrect answer --- */ question.correct_answer = 'VR and VC are affected!'; question.feedback = 'No, try again and look closely at your measurements with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 0; }
