questions.prompt: Measure the power supply voltage VPS in the circuit above.

subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ /* --- HOW MANY FREQ CHANGES? --- */ sparks.vars.fChange = function (f) { z = 0; y = f.sort(); len = y.length; for (var i = 1; i < len; i++) { if (y[i] != y[i - 1]) { z++; } } return (z); }; sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { if(component == 'PS') {nodes = 'gnd,powerPosL';} else nodes = component.getNodes(); /* --- allow for probes on power rails --- */ if (nodes.indexOf('L9') >-1) {nodes+= ',powerPosL';} else if (nodes.indexOf('powerPosL') >-1) {nodes+= ',L9';} if (nodes.indexOf('L21') >-1) {nodes+= ', gnd';} else if (nodes.indexOf('gnd') >-1) {nodes+= ',L21';} if(component == 'PS') {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure PS via ' + nodes + ' ?');} else {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure ' + component.UID + ' via ' + nodes + ' ?');} return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); /* --- RETURNS BOOLEAN RESULT --- */ }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe + ' meas value: ' + meta.val + ' ' + meta.units); var probesPS = ['PowerPosL', 'gnd', 'L21', 'L9']; /* --- encode valid PS measurements --- */ if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { console.log('Measured R where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, C)) { console.log('Measured C where C = ' + sparks.vars.C + ' H'); return ('C'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, 'PS')) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R or C or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK MEASURE OF x STORED IN q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== Checking measurements for this question:'); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ { q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.'; } } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement) /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ { if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: /* --- VS SCORING AT FREQ F1 --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');

subquestions.prompt: If VPS were all applied to the resistor R, so that VR equals VPS, we could obtain maximum power from the circuit. But because of the capacitance from C in this AC circuit, at lower frequency values, VR decreases, and the power available to R also decreases. At what voltage VR will it's power be reduced to half the maximum value?

options.option: [ /* --- FIRST OPPORTUNITY TO DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXC = function (C, f) { return (1/(2 * Math.PI * C * f)); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XC = sparks.vars.fXC(sparks.vars.C, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XC); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VC = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XC, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log(''); console.log('Recalc: f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ', XC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XC + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('At this f, VS = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS + 'V') +', VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT INDUCTANCE VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function (x, unit) { if (Math.log10(x) < -6) { /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100 * x * 1e9) / 100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHER --- */ { return (sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit)); } }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 300 + 160) / 10; /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C = C.getCapacitance(); sparks.vars.Cutoff = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * sparks.vars.R * sparks.vars.C); sparks.vars.RLoc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.CLoc = C.getNodes(); sparks.vars.mySqrt2 = '√2 '; sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); /* --- USE INITIAL FREQUENCY FOR DISTRACTERS --- */ sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); /* --- create distracters here and use them in scoring --- */ sparks.vars.a0 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS / Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk0 = 'Good! The circuit will have half the maximum power at VPS times 0.707, or VPS divided by ' + sparks.vars.mySqrt2 + '. '; sparks.vars.pts0 = 50; sparks.vars.a1 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS / 2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk1 = 'No, this is just half the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts1 = 0; sparks.vars.a2 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk2 = 'No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts2 = 0; sparks.vars.a3 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS * 2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk3 = 'No, that is twice the supply voltage, VPS. The capacitor impedance will cause VR to be less than the supply voltage. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts3 = 0; sparks.vars.a4 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk4 = 'No, you chose the full supply voltage value, VPS. Reduced power will occur with reduced voltage across R. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts4 = 0; sparks.vars.a5 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS * Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk5 = 'No, that is even more than the supply voltage, VPS. The capacitor impedance will cause VR to be less than the supply voltage. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts5 = 0; sparks.vars.a6 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC * Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk6 = 'No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts6 = 0; sparks.vars.a7 = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR * Math.SQRT2 + 'V'); sparks.vars.fbk7 = 'No, the half power point is based on the supply voltage, VPS. Check the tutorial for more help.'; sparks.vars.pts7 = 0; sparks.vars.a0; ]

subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.a0; question.points = sparks.vars.pts0; question.points_earned = 0; if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a0) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk0; question.points_earned = sparks.vars.pts0; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a1) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk1; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a2) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk2; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a3) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk3; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a4) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk4; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a5) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk5; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a6) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk6; } else if (question.answer == sparks.vars.a7) { question.feedback = sparks.vars.fbk7; }

questions.prompt:
What is the cutoff frequency for this circuit?
(pick the closest value)
questions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); /* --- update values since frequency may have changed --- */ question.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Cutoff + 'Hz'); question.points = 50; if (question.answer == question.correct_answer) { /* --- chosen answer is correct --- */ if (sparks.vars.dbugProbes(question.meta) == 'R' && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- probes placed right and frequency changes detected --- */ question.feedback = 'Right on! Near this frequency, the capacitor "impedes" half the maximum circuit power. This is called the cutoff frequency.'; question.points_earned = 50; } else { /* --- appears to be lucky guess --- */ question.feedback = 'Wow, did you guess at that answer? You need to measure VR while changing the frequency and watching for the voltage that reduces the power by half. Check out the tutorial.'; question.points_earned = 0; } } else { /* --- chosen answer is incorrect --- */ if (sparks.vars.dbugProbes(question.meta) == 'R') { /* --- measurements were made --- */ do_measure = ''; } else { do_measure = 'measure VR and '; } question.feedback = 'No. You need to ' + do_measure + 'find the frequency that drops the voltage to reduce the power to half of the maximum possible value. Check out the tutorial.'; question.points_earned = 0; }

doc.title: Measuring a RLC Series Circuit with DMM and Oscilloscope

circuit.comment: at this freq, C = 1/X, in microfarads
circuit.label: C

circuit.comment: at this freq, L = X, in milliHenrys
circuit.label: L

pages.notes:
[/* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXC = function (C, f) { return (1 / (2 * Math.PI * C * f)); }; sparks.vars.fXL = function (L, f) { return (2 * Math.PI * L * f); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XC = sparks.vars.fXC(sparks.vars.C, f); sparks.vars.XL = sparks.vars.fXL(sparks.vars.L, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XL - sparks.vars.XC); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VC = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XC, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VL = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XL, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log('Recalc: at f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ': R =' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.R + 'ohms') + ', XC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XC + 'ohms') + ', XL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XL + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Voltages VS = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS + 'V') + ', VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V') + ', VL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT SMALL C and L VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function (x, unit) { console.log('ConvertNano: x=' + x); if (Math.log10(x) < -7) { /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100 * x * 1e9) / 100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else if (Math.log10(x) < -6) { /* --- HANDLE 0.1 micro --- */ roundedMicroX = Math.round(1000 * x * 1e6) / 1000; return (roundedMicroX + ' μ' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHERS --- */ { convertedMeasX = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit); return (convertedMeasX); } }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C = C1.getCapacitance(); sparks.vars.L = L1.getInductance(); sparks.vars.Resonance = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * Math.sqrt(sparks.vars.L * sparks.vars.C)); sparks.vars.R1Loc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.C1Loc = C1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.L1Loc = L1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); ''] For this circuit:
   R = [sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(r1.resistance + ' ohms')]
   C = [sparks.vars.convertNano(sparks.vars.C,'f')]
   L = [sparks.vars.convertNano(sparks.vars.L,'H')]

questions.prompt: Adjust the function generator to near the middle of its frequency range, and use the DMM to measure the RMS voltage from the power supply, and across each component. (Hint: When the DMM shows a reading, click Read Multimeter button.)

subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fChange = function (f) { /* --- HOW MANY FREQ CHANGES? --- */ z = 0; y = f.sort(); len = y.length; for (var i = 1; i < len; i++) { if (y[i] > y[i - 1]) { z++; } } return (z); }; /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { if(component == 'PS') {nodes = 'gnd,powerPosL';} else nodes = component.getNodes(); /* --- allow for right half connected with wires at L5 and L23 --- */ if (nodes.indexOf('L5') >-1) {nodes+= ',powerPosL';} else if (nodes.indexOf('powerPosL') >-1) {nodes+= ',L5';} if (nodes.indexOf('L23') >-1) {nodes+= ',gnd';} else if (nodes.indexOf('gnd') >-1) {nodes+= ',L23';} if(component == 'PS') {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure PS via ' + nodes + ' ?');} else {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure ' + component.UID + ' via ' + nodes + ' ?');} return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); /* --- RETURNS BOOLEAN RESULT --- */ }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe); if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { return ('R'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, C1)) { return ('C'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, L1)) { return ('L'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, 'PS')) { return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R or C or L or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK DMM MEASURE OF COMPONENT x STORED IN QUESTION q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== CheckMeasurement comparing target: ' + target + ' with measured value ' + q.meta.val + ' for: ' + x); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ { q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.'; } } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); console.log('probes placed across: ' + probePlacement); if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { console.log('Yes! Probes across ' + x + ' as desired. Checking measurements...'); if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = q.points; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = Math.round(q.points/5); q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'Please connect the DMM probes and wait for the DMM display before clicking the Read Multimeter button. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = Math.round(q.points/5); q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement) { /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + probePlacement + ', not across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');
sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VR, 'R');
sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VC, 'C');
sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VL, 'L');

questions.prompt:
Vary the power supply frequency, and using either the oscilloscope or the DMM, observe the effect on VR. Which of the following statements best completes the sentence that describes the effect of various frequencies on the magnitude of VR:
As the frequency in an RLC circuit is increased, the circuit current I and voltage across the resistor VR...

options.option: increase to a maximum, and then decreases.
decrease to a minimum, and then increases.
decrease, along with the capacitor, while the inductor voltage rises greatly.
increase in proportion to the rising frequency.
decrease, in inverse proportion to the rising frequency.

questions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); question.correct_answer = 'VR increases to a maximum then decreases'; points = sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[1].points_earned + sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[2].points_earned + sparks.sectionController.currentPage.questions[3].points_earned; /*--- performance on previous questions --- */ if (question.answer.indexOf('and then decreases') > 0) { /* --- answer includes key phrase --- */ if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- right answer and frequencies were changed --- */ if (points > 50) { /* --- most of the previous questions answered OK --- */ question.feedback = 'Correct! As you saw, the capacitor and inductor combine to impede the AC current at low frequencies and high frequencies, reducing ' + 'the voltage across R. But somewhere in the middle, the AC current reaches a maximum. Feel free to experiment more, or repeat with different circuit values.'; question.points_earned = question.points; } else { /* --- or did not answer most of the previous questions correctly --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the voltage across the resistor reaches a maximum at a certain frequency, but were you able to measure and verify that? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with different circuit values and earn more points.'; question.points_earned = Math.round(question.points/5); } } else { /* --- right answer, but frequencies not explored --- */ if (points) { /* --- although at least one of the previous questions answered OK --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the voltage across the resistor reaches a maximum at a certain frequency, but can you verify that by some measurements? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with different circuit values and earn more points.'; question.points_earned = Math.round(question.points/10); } else { /* --- or did not answer any of the previous questions correctly --- */ question.feedback = 'Yes, the voltage across the resistor does reach a maximum at a certain frequency, but did you verify this with your measurements? You can try this now, or repeat the activity with different circuit values and earn more points.'; q.points_earned = Math.round(question.points/10); } } } else { /* --- incorrect answer --- */ question.feedback = 'No, try again and look closely at your measurements with different frequencies.'; question.points_earned = 0; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- user did change the frequency some --- */ question.feedback = 'No, try again and look closely at your measurements with different frequencies.'; } else { /* --- frequencies not explored --- */ question.feedback = 'No, try again, watching your measurements as you change the power supply frequency.'; } }

questions.prompt: You've seen that the voltages in an AC circuit can vary with the frequency, depending on the circuit components. In the RLC circuit here, as the frequency varies, what is the maximum DMM voltage measured across the capacitor? (Hint: Use the oscilloscope to "see" VC. Select the closest value below.)

options.option: [/* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fXC = function (C, f) { return (1 / (2 * Math.PI * C * f)); }; sparks.vars.fXL = function (L, f) { return (2 * Math.PI * L * f); }; sparks.vars.fZ = function (r, x) { return (Math.sqrt(r * r + x * x)); }; sparks.vars.fV = function (v, x, z) { return (Math.round(10 * v * x / z) / 10); }; sparks.vars.pctDiff = function (n1, n2) { return (Math.round(100 * Math.abs(n2 - n1) / n2 * 100) / 100 + '% diff'); }; /* --- RECALC FUNCTION AT FREQ f */ sparks.vars.Recalc = function (f) { sparks.vars.XC = sparks.vars.fXC(sparks.vars.C, f); sparks.vars.XL = sparks.vars.fXL(sparks.vars.L, f); sparks.vars.Z = sparks.vars.fZ(sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.XL - sparks.vars.XC); sparks.vars.VR = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.R, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VC = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XC, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.VL = sparks.vars.fV(sparks.vars.VS, sparks.vars.XL, sparks.vars.Z); sparks.vars.freqs.push(f); console.log('Recalc: at f = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(f + 'Hz') + ': R =' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.R + 'ohms') + ', XC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XC + 'ohms') + ', XL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.XL + 'ohms') + ', Z = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.Z + 'ohms')); console.log('Voltages VS = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VS + 'V') + ', VR = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VR + 'V') + ', VC = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VC + 'V') + ', VL = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VL + 'V')); }; /* --- CONVERT SMALL C and L VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.convertNano = function (x, unit) { console.log('ConvertNano: x=' + x); if (Math.log10(x) < -7) { /* --- HANDLE NANO --- */ roundedNanoX = Math.round(100 * x * 1e9) / 100; return (roundedNanoX + ' n' + unit); } else if (Math.log10(x) < -6) { /* --- HANDLE 0.1 micro --- */ roundedMicroX = Math.round(1000 * x * 1e6) / 1000; return (roundedMicroX + ' μ' + unit); } else /* --- ALL OTHERS --- */ { convertedMeasX = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(x + unit); return (convertedMeasX); } }; /*--- DEFINE RANDOM AMPLITUDE --- */ /* --- DEBUGGING-fix-starting-value--- source.amplitude = Math.round(Math.random() * 30 + 16); ---*/ /* --- STARTING VALUES --- */ sparks.vars.VS = source.amplitude / Math.sqrt(2); sparks.vars.R = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C = C1.getCapacitance(); sparks.vars.L = L1.getInductance(); sparks.vars.R1Loc = r1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.C1Loc = C1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.L1Loc = L1.getNodes(); sparks.vars.freqs = new Array(); sparks.vars.Resonance = 1 / (2 * Math.PI * Math.sqrt(sparks.vars.L * sparks.vars.C)); console.log('Calculate values at resonance frequency...'); sparks.vars.Recalc(sparks.vars.Resonance); /* --- save values at resonance --- */ sparks.vars.VCmax = sparks.vars.VC; sparks.vars.VLmax = sparks.vars.VL; sparks.vars.VRmax = sparks.vars.VR; sparks.vars.Recalc(source.initialFrequency); /* --- last value here is the choice to display --- */ sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(sparks.vars.VCmax + 'V'); ]

questions.prompt: Here are two series circuits, on the top and bottom half of a breadboard. A function generator powers both: an AC power supply delivering VPS. Both circuits have the same resistor R, capacitor C, and inductor L, but notice that L and C are reversed in each circuit. By varying the power supply frequency, you can explore how the frequency response of this RLC circuit. (Hint: You can use the DMM anywhere in the circuit, or the oscilloscope probes to measure with respect to circuit ground.)

subquestions.prompt:
Using the DMM, measure the RMS voltage from the power supply, and across each component: first, at a frequency near 1 kHz. (Hint: Connect the DMM probes, adjust the DMM (if needed), and click Read Multimeter button.)
 Supply voltage VPS
subquestions.beforeScript: /* --- BEFORESCRIPT --- */ /* --- DEFINE FUNCTIONS --- */ sparks.vars.fChange = function (f) { /* --- HOW MANY FREQ CHANGES? --- */ z = 0; y = f.sort(); len = y.length; for (var i = 1; i < len; i++) { if (y[i] > y[i - 1]) { z++; } } return (z); }; /* --- CHECK IF MEASUREMENTS MADE --- */ sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent = function (meta, component) { if(component == 'PS') {nodes = 'gnd,powerPosL';} else nodes = component.getNodes(); /* --- allow for right half connected with wires at L5 and L23 --- */ if (nodes.indexOf('L5') >-1) {nodes+= ',R5,powerPosL';} else if (nodes.indexOf('R5') >-1) {nodes+= ',L5,powerPosL';} else if (nodes.indexOf('powerPosL') >-1) {nodes+= ',L5,R5';} if (nodes.indexOf('L23') >-1) {nodes+= ',R23,gnd';} else if (nodes.indexOf('R23') >-1) {nodes+= ',L23,gnd';} else if (nodes.indexOf('gnd') >-1) {nodes+= ',L23,R23';} if(component == 'PS') {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure PS via ' + nodes + ' ?');} else {console.log('didMeasureComponent: checking: did you measure ' + component.UID + ' via ' + nodes + ' ?');} return (nodes.indexOf(meta.redProbe) > -1 && nodes.indexOf(meta.blackProbe) > -1 && meta.redProbe !== meta.blackProbe); /* --- RETURNS BOOLEAN RESULT --- */ }; /* --- CHECK PROBE PLACEMENTS ---*/ sparks.vars.dbugProbes = function (meta) { console.log('blackProbe: ' + meta.blackProbe + ' redProbe: ' + meta.redProbe); if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r1)) { console.log('Measured R1 where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R1'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, r2)) { console.log('Measured R2 where R = ' + sparks.vars.R + ' ohms'); return ('R2'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, C1)) { console.log('Measured C1 where C = ' + sparks.vars.C + ' f'); return ('C1'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, C2)) { console.log('Measured C2 where C = ' + sparks.vars.C + ' f'); return ('C2'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, L1)) { console.log('Measured L1 where L = ' + sparks.vars.L + ' H'); return ('L1'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, L2)) { console.log('Measured L2 where L = ' + sparks.vars.L + ' H'); return ('L2'); } else if (sparks.vars.didMeasureComponent(meta, 'PS')) { console.log('Measured PS where VS = ' + sparks.vars.VS + ' V'); return ('PS'); } else { console.log('NOT measuring R or C or L or PS'); return (-1); } }; /* --- CHECK DMM MEASURE OF COMPONENT x STORED IN QUESTION q, COMPARE TO target VOLTAGE --- */ sparks.vars.checkMeasurement = function (q, target, x) { console.log('====== CheckMeasurement comparing target: ' + target + ' with measured value ' + q.meta.val + ' for: ' + x); console.log(q); q.correct_answer = Math.round(10 * target) / 10; q.points_earned = 0; /* --- CHECK PROBES AND DMM SETUP --- */ if (!q.meta.units && !q.meta.val) { /* --- NO MEASUREMENT --- */ if (q.meta.blackProbe && q.meta.redProbe) { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT NO READING TAKEN--- */ q.feedback = 'Use the Read Multimeter button to record your circuit measurements.'; } else /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED AND NO READING TAKEN--- */ { q.feedback = 'Connect the DMM probes and use the Read Multimeter button to measure the circuit.'; } } else if (!q.meta.amplitude && isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- PROBES NOT PLACED IN CIRCUIT --- */ q.feedback = 'Connect both DMM probes to your circuit to make measurements.'; } else if (q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_200' && q.meta.dmmDial != 'acv_750') { /* --- PROBES PLACED BUT BAD DMM KNOB SET --- */ q.feedback = 'Use the DMM set to measure AC voltages.'; if (q.meta.val !== null && !isNaN(q.meta.val)) { /* --- GOT A READING ALBEIT BAD --- */ q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(Math.round(10000 * q.meta.val) / 10000 + ' ' + q.meta.units); } } else /* --- CHECK ACV READING --- */ { q.answer = Math.round(10 * q.meta.val) / 10; if (!q.meta.frequency) { /* --- FREQ NOT CHANGED, SO USE INIT FREQ --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = source.initialFrequency; } else { /* --- USE CURRENT FREQ VALUE --- */ sparks.vars.Freq = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.meta.frequency + 'Hz'); } probePlacement = sparks.vars.dbugProbes(q.meta); console.log('probes placed across: ' + probePlacement); /* --- CONVERT R1 or R2 to R, C1 or C2 to C, and L1 or L2 to L --- */ if(probePlacement != 'PS' && probePlacement) { if(probePlacement == 'R1' || probePlacement == 'R2') { console.log('so we are measuring R'); probePlacement = 'R';} else if(probePlacement == 'C1' || probePlacement == 'C2') { console.log('so we are measuring C'); probePlacement = 'C';} else if(probePlacement == 'L1' || probePlacement == 'L2') { console.log('so we are measuring L'); probePlacement = 'L';} else console.log('probes not across known component, but at ' + probePlacement); } if (probePlacement == x) /* --- YES, PROBES ACROSS x ---*/ { console.log('Yes! Probes across ' + x + ' as desired. Checking measurements...'); if (q.meta.dmmDial == 'acv_200') { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_200 ---*/ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { q.correct_answer = q.answer; if (sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) { /* --- BRAVO! ---*/ q.points_earned = 10; q.feedback = 'Excellent! You measured V' + x + ' at ' + sparks.vars.Freq; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'You measured well, but not at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- UKNOWN RESULT ---*/ q.feedback = 'The DMM appears to have malfunctioned. Sorry! Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ if (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('low') > 0 || (q.shortPrompt.indexOf('high') > 0 && sparks.vars.fChange(sparks.vars.freqs) > 0) || q.shortPrompt.indexOf('upply') > 0) { /* --- ALMOST RIGHT AND FREQ CHANGED OK ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- NO CHANGE OF FREQ ---*/ q.feedback = 'You need to use a more precise DMM setting, and at a different frequency, as directed.'; } } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but should use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement) { /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + probePlacement + ', not across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, even though the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'No, you need to measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V') + ' ' + sparks.vars.pctDiff(q.meta.val, target)); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */
subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VS, 'PS');
sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VR, 'R');
sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VC, 'C');
sparks.vars.Recalc(question.meta.frequency); sparks.vars.checkMeasurement(question, sparks.vars.VL, 'L');

questions.prompt: Vary the power supply frequency, and using either the oscilloscope or the DMM, observe the effect on VR. Which of the following statements best completes the sentence that describes the effect of various frequencies on VR: As you increase the frequency in an RLC circuit...

options.option: the voltage across the resistor increases to a maximum, and then decreases.
the voltage across the resistor decreases to a minimum, and then increases.
the voltage across the resistor and capacitor decrease, while the inductor voltage rises greatly.
the voltage across the resistor and inductor decrease, while the capacitor voltage rises greatly.
the voltage across the resistor remains constant, as the capacitor and inductor balance each other.

Try again?'; } } else { /* --- DMM KNOB ON ACV_750 ---*/ if (close(Math.round(target), q.answer, 20 / target)) { /* --- MEASURE IS CLOSE ---*/ q.points_earned = 2; q.feedback = 'Essentially right, but you need to use the most precise scale on the DMM for precision.'; } else { /* --- MEASURE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ q.feedback = 'You placed the probes in the right place, but need to use a more precise DMM setting. Sorry!'; } } } else if (probePlacement !== -1) /* --- PROBES ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT --- */ { if (close(target, q.answer, 15 / target)) { /* --- VALUE ACROSS WRONG COMPONENT IS CLOSE ---*/ console.log('close value, but bad probe placement: across ' + x); q.feedback = 'No, although the measures appear close, you did not measure across ' + x + '.'; } else { /* --- VALUE IS NOT CLOSE ---*/ if ((probePlacement == 'R1' && x == 'R2') || (probePlacement == 'R2' && x == 'R1') || target == sparks.vars.V - q.answer) { q.feedback = 'Did you get the measures from the two resistors reversed? Try again.'; } else { q.feedback = 'Please measure across ' + x + ' to find V' + x + '.'; } } } else { /* --- PROBE PLACEMENTS UNKNOWN ---*/ q.feedback = 'What happened? You did not appear to measure across ' + x + '.'; } q.correct_answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.correct_answer + 'V'); q.answer = sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(q.answer + q.meta.units); if (q.points_earned > 0) { sparks.vars.Score++; } } console.log('V' + x + ' @ ' + sparks.vars.Freq + ': Meas = ' + q.answer + ' Actual = ' + sparks.unit.convertMeasurement(target + 'V')); return; }; /* --- END CHECK MEASUREMENT --- */ /* --- END BEFORESCRIPT --- */

doc.title: Measuring an RCL circuit with an oscilloscope

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   The resistors have resistance = [r1.resistance] ohms
   The capacitors have capacitance = [c1.capacitance] farads
  The inductors have inductance = [l1.inductance] henries

questions.prompt:
Here is a circuit consisting of a resistor, a capacitor, and an inductor in series. We've reproduced the circuit twice, reversing the order of the capacitor and the inductor so that you can measure the voltage across either one.
First measure the voltage across the resistor and vary the frequency. Notice that the voltage varies as you change the frequency.

subquestions.prompt: What frequency maximizes the voltage across R1 (for the top circuit)?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'} question.feedback += ' Your goodnessOfScale for the OScope at the end was '+goodness;

subquestions.prompt: What frequency maximizes the voltage across R2 (for the bottom circuit)?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak-to-peak voltage across the resistor at this frequency?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   The resistors have resistance = [r1.resistance] ohms
   The capacitors have capacitance = [c1.capacitance] farads
  The inductors have inductance = [l1.inductance] henries

questions.prompt: The frequency that maximizes the voltage across the resistor (which is proportional to the current through the circuit) is called the resonance frequency. Using the top circuit, measure the voltage across the capacitor and the resistor at the resonance frequency. Then use the bottom circuit to measure the voltage across the inductor and the resistor and answer the questions below.

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak-to-peak voltage across R and C at resonance?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

subquestions.prompt: What is the peak-to-peak voltage across R and L at resonance?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   The resistors have resistance = [r1.resistance] ohms
   The capacitors have capacitance = [c1.capacitance] farads
  The inductors have inductance = [l1.inductance] henries

questions.prompt: Did you notice that the voltages across the capacitor and the inductor are much higher than across the resistor alone (about 170 volts)? Yet the total voltage across the resistor, capacitor and inductor is actually quite low (about 17 volts). How can that be??? Here's a hint: it has to do with the phase of the voltages, which you will measure below.

subquestions.prompt: What is the phase of the voltage across the resistor and the capacitor at resonance?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

subquestions.prompt: Does this voltage lag or lead the input voltage?

options.feedback: That's right!
No.

subquestions.prompt: What is the phase of the voltage across the resistor and the inductor at resonance?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

subquestions.prompt: Does this voltage lag or lead the input voltage?

options.feedback: That's right!
No.

questions.prompt: The voltages across the capacitor and the inductor are each 90 degrees out of phase with the input voltage but one of them lags the input voltage and the other one lags. Thus, the two voltages are 180 degrees (90 degrees times two) out of phase with each other and they exactly cancel out!

doc.title: Measuring an RCL circuit with an oscilloscope
Measuring an RC circuit with an oscilloscope

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   R1 = [r1.resistance] ohms
   C1 = [Math.round(10*c1.capacitance * 1000000)/10] microf
   R2 = [r2.resistance] ohms
   C2 = [Math.round(10*c2.capacitance * 1000000)/10] microf

questions.prompt:
Here are two RC circuits and an oscilloscope. The oscilloscope and the function generator share a common ground which is connected to the black lead of the function generator. Note that one of the oscilloscope probes (the yellow one) is permanently attached to ground so the oscilloscope measures all voltages with respect to ground.

The two circuits are subtly different. In the upper circuit the resistor is attached to the red lead of the function generator, in the lower circuit it is the capacitor that is attached to the red lead of the function generator.

This means that if you connect the probe to the junction between the resistor and the capacitor then in the upper circuit you are measuring the voltage across the resistor (which is proportional to the current through the circuit). But if you do the same measurement with the lower circuit you are measuring the voltage across the capacitor.

Set the frequency on the function generator and then make the measurements below.

subquestions.prompt: Measure the peak voltage across the resistor.
subquestions.scoring: sparks.vars.R1 = r1.resistance; sparks.vars.C1 = c1.capacitance; sparks.vars.f = question.meta.frequency; sparks.vars.V1 = source.amplitude; sparks.vars.Z1 = 1/(6.2832*sparks.vars.f*sparks.vars.C1); sparks.vars.Ztotal = Math.sqrt(Math.pow(sparks.vars.R1,2)+Math.pow(sparks.vars.Z1,2)); sparks.vars.Vr1 = Math.round(10*(sparks.vars.V1*sparks.vars.R1/sparks.vars.Ztotal))/10; sparks.vars.Vc1 = Math.round(10*(sparks.vars.V1*sparks.vars.Z1/sparks.vars.Ztotal))/10; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.Vr1 + ' volts'; var valueCorrect = false; var unitsCorrect = false; if(question.answer != '') {var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); var valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, sparks.vars.Vr1, 10); var unitsExist = !!parsedAnswer.units; if (unitsExist) {unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'}; question.points_earned = (valueCorrect ? 500 : 0) + (unitsCorrect ? 100 : 0); question.feedback = (valueCorrect ? 'You got the value correct' : 'You did not get the value correct') + (unitsCorrect ? ' and you got the units correct' : ' and you did not get the units correct')} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

subquestions.prompt: Without changing the frequency, measure the peak voltage across the capacitor
subquestions.scoring: question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.Vc1 + ' volts'; var valueCorrect = false; var unitsCorrect = false; if(question.answer != '') {var parsedAnswer = parse(question.answer); valueCorrect = close(parsedAnswer.val, sparks.vars.Vc1, 10); var unitsExist = !!parsedAnswer.units; if (unitsExist) { unitsCorrect = parsedAnswer.units === 'V'}; question.points_earned = (valueCorrect ? 500 : 0) + (unitsCorrect ? 100 : 0); question.feedback = (valueCorrect ? 'You got the value correct' : 'You did not get the value correct') + (unitsCorrect ? ' and you got the units correct' : ' and you did not get the units correct')} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

questions.prompt: Now try changing the frequency and see if any of your measurements change. (Remember: to change the frequency, click on the thumbnail of the function generator and move the slider.) Set a different frequency and make the same measurements. Does changing the frequency affect the measurements you just made?
questions.shortPrompt: Measuring RC voltages at second frequency

subquestions.prompt: Measure the peak voltage across the resistor at this new frequency.
Without changing the frequency, measure the peak voltage across the capacitor

questions.prompt: Compare the new measurements to the old ones and answer the question below

options.option: None of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Wrong! Try again and be careful!

options.option: Some of my measurements change when I change the frequency, but not all.
options.feedback: That's right! The total voltage is still the same, but the voltage drops across the resistor and the capacitor change when you change the frequency.

options.option: All of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Actually, that is not so. Two of them change but the third measurement isn't affected by the frequency. Try again!

questions.prompt: Is the voltage across R and C equal to the voltage across R plus the voltage across C?

options.feedback: Wrong! The voltage drops across the components do not add up to the total applied voltage, the way they do with resistors.
Right! The voltage drops across the components do not add up to the total applied voltage, the way they do with resistors.

doc.title: Two resistors in series, AC source, DMM and Oscilloscope

pages.notes:
For this circuit:
   R1 = [r1.resistance] ohms
   R2 = [r2.resistance] ohms
   R3 = [r3.resistance] ohms
   R4 = [r4.resistance] ohms

questions.prompt:
The circuit on the top half of the breadboard is the same one you saw before, the one on the bottom half has the same resistors but in the reverse order. And this time you've got an oscillscope in addition to the digital multimeter. This activity will help you understand how the oscilloscope and the multimeter measure voltage.

First click on the function generator and set the frequency, then measure the voltage across R1 (or R4 -- they're the same) using the multimeter. (You can read the labels on the resistors by mousing over them.)
questions.scoring: question.answer = Math.round(10 * question.answer)/10; sparks.vars.Vrms = Math.round(10 * source.amplitude/Math.sqrt(2))/10; sparks.vars.V1 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.Vrms * r1.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; sparks.vars.V2 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.Vrms * r2.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; sparks.vars.V3 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.Vrms * r3.resistance/(r3.resistance + r4.resistance))/10;sparks.vars.V4 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.Vrms * r4.resistance/(r3.resistance + r4.resistance))/10; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.V1 + ' volts';if(question.answer != null) {if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V1 - question.answer) < .01){question.points_earned = 400; question.feedback = 'Excellent!'} else if(Math.abs(sparks.vars.V2 - question.answer) < .01) {question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R2 or R3.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if(Math.abs(sparks.vars.V3 - question.answer) < .01) {question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R2 or R3.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.Vrms - question.answer) < .01){question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across both resistors.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(question.answer) < .0001){question.feedback = 'Make sure the DMM is set to measure AC voltage before you make the measurement.'; question.points_earned = 0};} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

questions.prompt: Now measure the voltage across R2 using the multimeter.

questions.prompt:
Now try making the same two measurements using the oscilloscope. Note that the oscilloscope has only one probe, not two. It measures voltages with respect to a ground voltage. The oscilloscope and the function generator share a common ground which is connected to the black lead of the function generator.

Place the oscilloscope probe so that it measures the voltage across R1 and enter the peak voltage below:

options.feedback: No, that's the peak voltage across both resistors.
Correct!
No, that's the peak voltage across R2 and R3.

questions.prompt: You can't measure the voltage across R2 with the oscilloscope unless you change the circuit! This is because the oscilloscope only measures voltages to ground. At the moment you can't move the resistors around on the breadboatd, but that's why we provided you with that lower circuit -- R3 and R4 and the same as R2 and R1, respectively, but they're in the reverse order, so you can measure the voltage across R3 and it will be the same as that across R2. Measure the voltage across R3 with the oscilloscope.

options.feedback: No, that's the peak voltage across both resistors.
Correct!
No, that's the peak voltage across R1 and R4.

questions.prompt: Is the peak voltage across the resistors, as measured with the oscilloscope, the same as the voltage measured with the multimeter?

options.feedback: No! The multimeter measures a kind of average voltage (the root-mean-square voltage), not the peak voltage. The multimeter reading is approximately 70% of the oscilloscope measurement.

That's right! The multimeter measures a kind of average voltage (it's called the root-mean-square voltage), not the peak voltage. The multimeter reading is approximately 70% of the oscilloscope measurement.

pages.notes:

questions.prompt:
Here is a circuit consisting of a resistor, a capacitor, and an inductor in series. We've reproduced the circuit twice, reversing the order of the capacitor and the inductor so that you can measure the voltage across either one.
First measure the voltage across the resistor and vary the frequency. Notice that the voltage varies as you change the frequency.

questions.prompt: The frequency that maximizes the voltage across the resistor (which is proportional to the current through the circuit) is called the resonance frequency. Using the top circuit, measure the voltage across the capacitor and the resistor at the resonance frequency. Then use the bottom circuit to measure the voltage across the inductor and the resistor and answer the questions below.

questions.prompt: Did you notice that the voltages across the capacitor and the inductor are much higher than across the resistor alone (about 170 volts)? Yet the total voltage across the resistor, capacitor and inductor is actually quite low (about 17 volts). How can that be??? Here's a hint: it has to do with the phase of the voltages, which you will measure below.

subquestions.prompt: What is the phase of the voltage across the resistor and the capacitor at resonance?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

subquestions.prompt: Does this voltage lag or lead the input voltage?

options.feedback: That's right!
No.

subquestions.prompt: What is the phase of the voltage across the resistor and the inductor at resonance?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer) {if(question.answer = question.correct_answer){question.feedback = 'Great!';question.points_earned = 100}} else {question.feedback = 'You did not answer this question.'}

subquestions.prompt: Does this voltage lag or lead the input voltage?

options.feedback: That's right!
No.

questions.prompt: The voltages across the capacitor and the inductor are each 90 degrees out of phase with the input voltage but one of them lags the input voltage and the other one lags. Thus, the two voltages are 180 degrees (90 degrees times two) out of phase with each other and they exactly cancel out!

doc.title: Measuring an RL circuit with an alternating voltage source

questions.prompt: In this circuit we've replaced the capacitor by an inductor. Your job is to figure out how the inductor behaves when you change the frequency. The circuit is driven by the same function generator as before. Make as many measurements as you want and then answer the questions below.

subquestions.prompt: Do the voltage drops across the components change with frequency?

options.option: None of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Wrong! Try again!

options.option: Some of my measurements change when I change the frequency, but not all.
options.feedback: That's right! The total voltage is still the same, but the voltage drops across the resistor and the inductor change when you change the frequency.

options.option: All of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Actually, that is not so. Two of them change but the third measurement isn't affected by the frequency. Try again!

subquestions.prompt: Is the voltage across R and L equal to the voltage across R plus the voltage across L

options.feedback: Wrong! The voltage drops across the components do not add up to the total applied voltage, the way they do with resistors.
Right! The voltage drops across the components do not add up to the total applied voltage, the way they do with resistors.

questions.prompt: How does the effective resistance (the correct term is 'impedance') of the inductor change with frequency?

options.option: The impedance of the inductor increases when the frequency is increased.
options.feedback: Correct!

options.option: The impedance of the inductor decreases when the frequency is increased.
options.feedback: No, actually the impedance of the inductor increases with increasing frequency.

options.option: The impedance of the inductor stays the same when the frequency is increased.
options.feedback: No, actually the impedance of the inductor increases with increasing frequency.

doc.title: Measuring a circuit with an alternating voltage source and two resistors in series

pages.notes:

questions.prompt: This is a simple circuit that you've seen many times before. It consists of just two resistances in series, but instead of being driven by a battery, this circuit is connected to a device called a function generator. The function generator produces an alternating voltage at a frequency that you can adjust. Measure the voltages below (hint: remember to set the digital multimeter to AC voltage!) and click to import the multimeter reading to the answer box.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage across R1?
subquestions.scoring: if(question.answer != null) {/*the student answered the question*/question.answer = Math.round(10 * question.answer)/10; sparks.vars.V = Math.round(10 * source.amplitude/Math.sqrt(2))/10; sparks.vars.V1 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r1.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; sparks.vars.V2 = Math.round(10 * sparks.vars.V * r2.resistance/(r1.resistance + r2.resistance))/10; if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V1 - question.answer) < .01){question.points_earned = 100; question.feedback = 'Excellent!'} else if(Math.abs(sparks.vars.V2 - question.answer) < .01) {question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across R2.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(sparks.vars.V - question.answer) < .01){question.feedback = 'No, that is the voltage across both resistors.'; question.points_earned = 0} else if (Math.abs(question.answer) < .0001){question.feedback = 'Make sure the DMM is set to measure AC voltage before you make the measurement.'; question.points_earned = 0}; question.correct_answer = sparks.vars.V1 + ' volts'} else {question.feedback = 'You did not make this measurement.'}

options.option: None of my measurements change when I change the frequency.
options.feedback: Right! Changing the frequency has no effect on the voltage drop across a resistor.

options.option: Some of my measurements change when I change the frequency, but not all.
options.feedback: Actually, that is not so. Try again and see!

options.option: All of my measurements change when I change the frequency.

questions.prompt: One last question: do the voltage drops across the two individual resistors always add up to the total voltage drop (across both resistors), regardless of the frequency?

options.feedback: That's right! Even though this is an alternating voltge source, the voltages across the two resistors always add up to the total voltage applied -- just as they did with the battery.
You said that the voltages across the two resistors didn't add up to the total voltage applied. That's not true, try again.
